speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I Thought the King had more aﬀeƈted the
Duke of Albany, then Cornwall.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: It did alwayes ſeeme ſo to vs: But
now in the diuiſion of the Kingdome, it ap-
peares not which of the Dukes hee valewes
moſt, for qualities are ſo weigh’d, that curioſity in nei-
ther, can make choiſe of eithers moity.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Is not this your Son, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: His breeding Sir, hath bin at my charge. I haue
ſo often bluſh’d to acknowledge him, that now I am
braz’d too’t.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I cannot conceiue you.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Sir, this yong Fellowes mother could; where-
vpon ſhe grew round womb’d, and had indeede (Sir) a
Sonne for her Cradle, ere ſhe had a husband for her bed.
Do you ſmell a fault?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I cannot wiſh the fault vndone, the iſſue of it,
being ſo proper.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: But I haue a Sonne, Sir, by order of Law, ſome
yeere elder then this; who, yet is no deerer in my ac-
count, though this Knaue came ſomthing ſawcily to the
world before he was ſent for: yet was his Mother fayre,
there was good ſport at his making, and the horſon muſt
be acknowledged. Doe you know this Noble Gentle-
man, Edmond?

speech.speaker: Edm.
speech.line: No, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: My Lord of Kent:
Remember him heereafter, as my Honourable Friend.

speech.speaker: Edm.
speech.line: My ſeruices to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I muſt loue you, and ſue to know you better.

speech.speaker: Edm.
speech.line: Sir, I ſhall ſtudy deſeruing.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: He hath bin out nine yeares, and away he ſhall
againe. The King is comming.

scene.stagedir: Sennet. Enter King Lear, Cornwall, Albany, Gonerill, Regan, Cordelia, and attendants.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Attend the Lords of France & Burgundy, Gloſter.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I ſhall, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Meane time we ſhal expreſſe our darker purpoſe.
Giue me the Map there. Know, that we haue diuided
In three our Kingdome: and ’tis our faſt intent,
To ſhake all Cares and Buſineſſe from our Age,
Conferring them on yonger ſtrengths, while we
Vnburthen’d crawle toward death. Our ſon of Cornwal,
And you our no leſſe louing Sonne of Albany,
We haue this houre a conſtant will to publiſh
Our daughters ſeuerall Dowers, that future ſtrife
May be preuented now. The Princes, France & Burgundy,
Great Riuals in our yongeſt daughters loue,
Long in our Court, haue made their amorous ſoiourne,
And heere are to be anſwer’d. Tell me my daughters
(Since now we will diueſt vs both of Rule,
Intereſt of Territory, Cares of State)
Which of you ſhall we ſay doth loue vs moſt,
That we, our largeſt bountie may extend
Where Nature doth with merit challenge. Gonerill,
Our eldeſt borne, ſpeake ﬁrſt.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Sir, I loue you more then word can weild ý matter,
Deerer then eye-ſight, ſpace, and libertie,
Beyond what can be valewed, rich or rare,
No leſſe then life, with grace, health, beauty, honor:
As much as Childe ere lou’d, or Father found.
A loue that makes breath poore, and ſpeech vnable,
Beyond all manner of ſo much I loue you.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What ſhall Cordelia ſpeake? Loue, and be ſilent.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Of all theſe bounds euen from this Line, to this,
With ſhadowie Forreſts, and with Champains rich’d
With plenteous Riuers, and wide-skirted Meades
We make thee Lady. To thine and Albanies iſſues
Be this perpetuall. What ſayes our ſecond Daughter?
Our deereſt Regan, wife of Cornwall?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I am made of that ſelfe-mettle as my Siſter,
And prize me at her worth. In my true heart,
I ﬁnde ſhe names my very deede of loue:
Onely ſhe comes too ſhort, that I profeſſe
My ſelfe an enemy to all other ioyes,
Which the moſt precious ſquare of ſenſe profeſſes,
And ﬁnde I am alone felicitate
In your deere Highneſſe loue.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Then poore Cordelia,
And yet not ſo, ſince I am ſure my loue’s
More ponderous then my tongue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To thee, and thine hereditarie euer,
Remaine this ample third of our faire Kingdome,
No leſſe in ſpace, validitie, and pleaſure
Then that conferr’d on Gonerill. Now our Ioy,
Although our laſt and leaſt; to whoſe yong loue,
The Vines of France, and Milke of Burgundie,
Striue to be intereſt. What can you ſay, to draw
A third, more opilent then your Siſters? ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nothing?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Nothing.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nothing will come of nothing, ſpeake againe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Vnhappie that I am, I cannot heaue
My heart into my mouth: I loue your Maieſty
According to my bond, no more nor leſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How, how Cordelia? Mend your ſpeech a little,
Leaſt you may marre your Fortunes.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Good my Lord,
You haue begot me, bred me, lou’d me.
I returne thoſe duties backe as are right ﬁt,
Obey you, Loue you, and moſt Honour you.
Why haue my Siſters Husbands, if they ſay
They loue you all? Happily when I ſhall wed,
That Lord, whoſe hand muſt take my plight, ſhall carry
Halfe my loue with him, halfe my Care, and Dutie,
Sure I ſhall neuer marry like my Siſters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: But goes thy heart with this?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So young, and ſo vntender?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: So young my Lord, and true.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let it be ſo, thy truth then be thy dowre:
For by the ſacred radience of the Sunne,
The miſteries of Heccat and the night:
By all the operation of the Orbes,
From whom we do exiſt, and ceaſe to be,
Heere I diſclaime all my Paternall care,
Propinquity and property of blood,
And as a ſtranger to my heart and me,
Hold thee from this for euer. The barbarous Scythian,
Or he that makes his generation meſſes
To gorge his appetite, ſhall to my boſome
Be as well neighbour’d, pittied, and releeu’d,
As thou my ſometime Daughter.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Liege.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Peace Kent,
Come not betweene the Dragon and his wrath,
I lou’d her moſt, and thought to ſet my reſt
On her kind nurſery. Hence and avoid my ſight:
So be my graue my peace, as here I giue
Her Fathers heart from her; call France, who ſtirres?
Call Burgundy, Cornwall, and Albanie,
With my two Daughters Dowres, digeſt the third,
Let pride, which ſhe cals plainneſſe, marry her:
I doe inueſt you ioyntly with my power,
Preheminence, and all the large eﬀeƈts
That troope with Maieſty. Our ſelfe by Monthly courſe,
With reſeruation of an hundred Knights,
By you to be ſuſtain’d, ſhall our abode
Make with you by due turne, onely we ſhall retaine
The name, and all th’ addition to a King: the Sway,
Reuennew, Execution of the reſt,
Beloued Sonnes be yours, which to conﬁrme,
This Coronet part betweene you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Royall Lear,
Whom I haue euer honor’d as my King,
Lou’d as my Father, as my Maſter follow’d,
As my great Patron thought on in my praiers.

speech.speaker: Le.
speech.line: The bow is bent & drawne, make from the ſhaft.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Let it fall rather, though the forke inuade
The region of my heart, be Kent vnmannerly,
When Lear is mad, what wouldeſt thou do old man?
Think’ſt thou that dutie ſhall haue dread to ſpeake,
When power to ﬂattery bowes?
To plainneſſe honour’s bound,
When Maieſty falls to folly, reſerue thy ſtate,
And in thy beſt conſideration checke
This hideous raſhneſſe, anſwere my life, my iudgement:
Thy yongeſt Daughter do’s not loue thee leaſt,
Nor are thoſe empty hearted, whoſe low ſounds
Reuerbe no hollowneſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Kent, on thy life no more.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My life I neuer held but as pawne
To wage againſt thine enemies, nere feare to looſe it,
Thy ſafety being motiue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Out of my ſight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: See better Lear, and let me ſtill remaine
The true blanke of thine eie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now by Apollo,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Now by Apollo, King
Thou ſwear’ſt thy Gods in vaine.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O Vaſſall! Miſcreant.

speech.speaker: Alb. Cor.
speech.line: Deare Sir forbeare.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Kill thy Phyſition, and thy fee beſtow
Vpon the foule diſeaſe, reuoke thy guift,
Or whil’ſt I can vent clamour from my throate,
Ile tell thee thou doſt euill.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: Heare me recreant, on thine allegeance heare me;
That thou haſt ſought to make vs breake our vowes,
Which we durſt neuer yet; and with ſtrain’d pride,
To come betwixt our ſentences, and our power,
Which, nor our nature, nor our place can beare;
Our potencie made good, take thy reward.
Fiue dayes we do allot thee for prouiſion,
To ſhield thee from diſaſters of the world,
And on the ſixt to turne thy hated backe
Vpon our kingdome: if on the tenth day following,
Thy baniſht trunke be found in our Dominions,
The moment is thy death, away. By Iupiter,
This ſhall not be reuok’d,

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Fare thee well King, ſith thus thou wilt appeare,
Freedome liues hence, and baniſhment is here;
The Gods to their deere ſhelter take thee Maid,
That iuſtly think’ſt, and haſt moſt rightly ſaid:
And your large ſpeeches, may your deeds approue,
That good eﬀeƈts may ſpring from words of loue:
Thus Kent, O Princes, bids you all adew,
Hee’l ſhape his old courſe, in a Country new.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Gloſter with France, and Burgundy, Attendants.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Heere’s France and Burgundy, my Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My Lord of Burgundie,
We ﬁrſt addreſſe toward you, who with this King
Hath riuald for our Daughter; what in the leaſt
Will you require in preſent Dower with her,
Or ceaſe your queſt of Loue?

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: Moſt Royall Maieſty,
I craue no more then hath your Highneſſe oﬀer’d,
Nor will you tender leſſe?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Right Noble Burgundy,
When ſhe was deare to vs, we did hold her ſo,
But now her price is fallen: Sir, there ſhe ſtands,
If ought within that little ſeeming ſubſtance,
Or all of it with our diſpleaſure piec’d,
And nothing more may ﬁtly like your Grace,
Shee’s there, and ſhe is yours.

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: I know no anſwer.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Will you with thoſe inﬁrmities ſhe owes,
Vnfriended, new adopted to our hate,
Dow’rd with our curſe, and ſtranger’d with our oath,
Take her or, leaue her.

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: Pardon me Royall Sir,
Eleƈtion makes not vp in ſuch conditions.

speech.speaker: Le.
speech.line: Then leaue her ſir, for by the powre that made me,
I tell you all her wealth. For you great King,
I would not from your loue make ſuch a ſtray,
To match you where I hate, therefore beſeech you
T’ auert your liking a more worthier way,
Then on a wretch whom Nature is aſham’d
Almoſt t’ acknowledge hers.

speech.speaker: Fra.
speech.line: This is moſt ſtrange,
That ſhe whom euen but now, was your obieƈt,
The argument of your praiſe, balme of your age,
The beſt, the deereſt, ſhould in this trice of time
Commit a thing ſo monſtrous, to diſmantle
So many folds of fauour: ſure her oﬀence
Muſt be of ſuch vnnaturall degree,
That monſters it: Or your fore-voucht aﬀeƈtion
Fall into taint, which to beleeue of her
Muſt be a faith that reaſon without miracle
Should neuer plant in me.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I yet beſeech your Maieſty.
If for I want that glib and oylie Art,
To ſpeake and purpoſe not, ſince what I will intend,
Ile do’t before I ſpeake, that you make knowne
It is no vicious blot, murther, or fouleneſſe,
No vnchaſte aƈtion or diſhonoured ſtep
That hath depriu’d me of your Grace and fauour,
But euen for want of that, for which I am richer,
A ſtill ſoliciting eye, and ſuch a tongue,
That I am glad I haue not, though not to haue it,
Hath loſt me in your liking.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Better thou had’ſt
Not beene borne, then not t’haue pleas’d me better.

speech.speaker: Fra.
speech.line: Is it but this? A tardineſſe in nature,
Which often leaues the hiſtory vnſpoke
That it intends to do: my Lord of Burgundy,
What ſay you to the Lady? Loue’s not loue
When it is mingled with regards, that ſtands
Aloofe from th’ intire point, will you haue her?
She is herſelfe a Dowrie.

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: Royall King,
Giue but that portion which your ſelfe propos’d,
And here I take Cordelia by the hand,
Dutcheſſe of Burgundie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nothing, I haue ſworne, I am ﬁrme.

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: I am ſorry then you haue ſo loſt a Father,
That you muſt looſe a husband.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Peace be with Burgundie,
Since that reſpeƈt and Fortunes are his loue,
I ſhall not be his wife.

speech.speaker: Fra.
speech.line: Faireſt Cordelia, that art moſt rich being poore,
Moſt choiſe forſaken, and moſt lou’d deſpis’d,
Thee and thy vertues here I ſeize vpon,
Be it lawfull I take vp what’s caſt away.
Gods, Gods! ’Tis ſtrange, that from their cold’ſt negleƈt
My Loue ſhould kindle to enﬂam’d reſpeƈt.
Thy dowreleſſe Daughter King, throwne to my chance,
Is Queene of vs, of ours, and our faire France:
Not all the Dukes of watriſh Burgundy,
Can buy this vnpriz’d precious Maid of me.
Bid them farewell Cordelia, though vnkinde,
Thou looſeſt here a better where to ﬁnde.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou haſt her France, let her be thine, for we
Haue no ſuch Daughter, nor ſhall euer ſee
That face of hers againe, therfore be gone,
Without our Grace, our Loue, our Benizon:
Come Noble Burgundie.

speech.speaker: Fra.
speech.line: Bid farwell to your Siſters.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: The Iewels of our Father, with waſh’d eies
Cordelia leaues you, I know you what you are,
And like a Siſter am moſt loth to call
Your faults as they are named. Loue well our Father:
To your profeſſed boſomes I commit him,
But yet alas, ſtood I within his Grace,
I would prefer him to a better place,
So farewell to you both.

speech.speaker: Regn.
speech.line: Preſcribe not vs our dutie.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Let your ſtudy
Be to content your Lord, who hath receiu’d you
At Fortunes almes, you haue obedience ſcanted,
And well are worth the want that you haue wanted.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Time ſhall vnfold what plighted cunning hides,
Who couers faults, at laſt with ſhame derides:
Well may you proſper.

speech.speaker: Fra
speech.line: Come my faire Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Siſter, it is not little I haue to ſay,
Of what moſt neerely appertaines to vs both,
I thinke our Father will hence to night.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: That’s moſt certaine, and with you: next moneth with vs.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: You ſee how full of changes his age is, the ob-
ſeruation we haue made of it hath beene little; he alwaies
lou’d our Siſter moſt, and with what poore iudgement he
hath now caſt her oﬀ, appeares too groſſely.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: ’Tis the inﬁrmity of his age, yet he hath euer but
ſlenderly knowne himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: The beſt and ſoundeſt of his time hath bin but
raſh, then muſt we looke from his age, to receiue not a-
lone the imperfeƈtions of long ingraﬀed condition, but
therewithall the vnruly way-wardneſſe, that inﬁrme and
cholericke yeares bring with them.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Such vnconſtant ſtarts are we like to haue from
him, as this of Kents baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: There is further complement of leaue-taking be-
tweene France and him, pray you let vs ſit together, if our
Father carry authority with ſuch diſpoſition as he beares,
this laſt ſurrender of his will but oﬀend vs.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: We ſhall further thinke of it.

speech.speaker: Gon
speech.line: We muſt do ſomething, and i’th’ heate.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Thou Nature art my Goddeſſe, to thy Law
My ſeruices are bound, wherefore ſhould I
Stand in the plague of cuſtome, and permit
The curioſity of Nations, to depriue me?
For that I am ſome twelue, or fourteene Moonſhines
Lag of a Brother? Why Baſtard? Wherefore baſe?
When my Dimenſions are as well compaƈt,
My minde as generous, and my ſhape as true
As honeſt Madams iſſue? Why brand they vs
With Baſe? With baſenes Baſtardie? Baſe, Baſe?
Who in the luſtie ſtealth of Nature, take
More compoſition, and ﬁerce qualitie,
Then doth within a dull ſtale tyred bed
Goe to th’ creating a whole tribe of Fops
Got ’tweene a ſleepe, and wake? Well then,
Legitimate Edgar, I muſt haue your land,
Our Fathers loue, is to the Baſtard Edmond,
As to th’ legitimate: ﬁne word: Legitimate.
Well, my Legittimate, if this Letter ſpeed,
And my inuention thriue, Edmond the baſe
Shall to’th’ Legitimate: I grow, I proſper:
Now Gods, ſtand vp for Baſtards.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Kent baniſh’d thus? and France in choller parted?
And the King gone to night? Preſcrib’d his powre,
Conﬁn’d to exhibition? All this done
Vpon the gad? Edmond, how now? What newes?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Lordſhip, none.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Why ſo earneſtly ſeeke you to put vp ý Letter?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I know no newes, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: What Paper were you reading?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: No? what needed then that terrible diſpatch of
it into your Pocket? The quality of nothing, hath not
ſuch neede to hide it ſelfe. Let’s ſee: come, if it bee no-
thing, I ſhall not neede Speƈtacles.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I beſeech you Sir, pardon mee; it is a Letter
from my Brother, that I haue not all ore-read; and for ſo
much as I haue perus’d, I ﬁnde it not ﬁt for your ore-loo-
king.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Giue me the Letter, Sir.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I ſhall oﬀend, either to detaine, or giue it:
The Contents, as in part I vnderſtand them,
Are too blame.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Let’s ſee, let’s ſee.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I hope for my Brothers iuſtiﬁcation, hee wrote
this but as an eſſay, or taſte of my Vertue.

line.recite: This policie, and reuerence of Age, makes the
world bitter to the beſt of our times: keepes our Fortunes from
vs, till our oldneſſe cannot relliſh them. I begin to ﬁnde an idle
and fond bondage, in the oppreſſion of aged tyranny, who ſwayes
not as it hath power, but as it is ſuﬀer’d. Come to me, that of
this I may ſpeake more. If our Father would ſleepe till I wak’d
him, you ſhould enioy halfe his Reuennew for euer, and liue the
beloued of your Brother. Edgar.

speech.line: Hum? Conſpiracy? Sleepe till I wake him, you ſhould
enioy halfe his Reuennew: my Sonne Edgar, had hee a
hand to write this? A heart and braine to breede it in?
When came you to this? Who brought it?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: It was not brought mee, my Lord; there’s the
cunning of it. I found it throwne in at the Caſement of
my Cloſſet.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: You know the charaƈter to be your Brothers?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If the matter were good my Lord, I durſt ſwear
it were his: but in reſpeƈt of that, I would faine thinke it
were not.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: It is his.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: It is his hand, my Lord: but I hope his heart is
not in the Contents.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Has he neuer before ſounded you in this buſines?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Neuer my Lord. But I haue heard him oft main-
taine it to be ﬁt, that Sonnes at perfeƈt age, and Fathers
declin’d, the Father ſhould bee as Ward to the Son, and
the Sonne manage his Reuennew.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: O Villain, villain: his very opinion in the Let-
ter. Abhorred Villaine, vnnaturall, deteſted, brutiſh
Villaine; worſe then brutiſh: Go ſirrah, ſeeke him: Ile
apprehend him. Abhominable Villaine, where is he?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I do not well know my L. If it ſhall pleaſe you to
ſuſpend your indignation againſt my Brother, til you can
deriue from him better teſtimony of his intent, you ſhold
run a certaine courſe: where, if you violently proceed a-
gainſt him, miſtaking his purpoſe, it would make a great
gap in your owne Honor, and ſhake in peeces, the heart of
his obedience. I dare pawne downe my life for him, that
he hath writ this to feele my aﬀeƈtion to your Honor, &
to no other pretence of danger.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Thinke you ſo?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If your Honor iudge it meete, I will place you
where you ſhall heare vs conferre of this, and by an Auri-
cular aſſurance haue your ſatisfaƈtion, and that without
any further delay, then this very Euening.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: He cannot bee ſuch a Monſter. Edmond ſeeke
him out: winde me into him, I pray you: frame the Bu-
ſineſſe after your owne wiſedome. I would vnſtate my
ſelfe, to be in a due reſolution.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I will ſeeke him Sir, preſently: conuey the bu-
ſineſſe as I ſhall ﬁnd meanes, and acquaint you withall.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Theſe late Eclipſes in the Sun and Moone por-
tend no good to vs: though the wiſedome of Nature can
reaſon it thus, and thus, yet Nature ﬁnds it ſelfe ſcourg’d
by the ſequent eﬀeƈts. Loue cooles, friendſhip falls oﬀ,
Brothers diuide. In Cities, mutinies; in Countries, diſ-
cord; in Pallaces, Treaſon; and the Bond crack’d, ’twixt
Sonne and Father. This villaine of mine comes vnder the
prediƈtion; there’s Son againſt Father, the King fals from
byas of Nature, there’s Father againſt Childe. We haue
ſeene the beſt of our time. Machinations, hollowneſſe,
treacherie, and all ruinous diſorders follow vs diſquietly
to our Graues. Find out this Villain, Edmond, it ſhall loſe
thee nothing, do it carefully: and the Noble & true-har-
ted Kent baniſh’d; his oﬀence, honeſty. ’Tis ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: This is the excellent foppery of the world, that
when we are ſicke in fortune, often the ſurfets of our own
behauiour, we make guilty of our diſaſters, the Sun, the
Moone, and Starres, as if we were villaines on neceſſitie,
Fooles by heauenly compulſion, Knaues, Theeues, and
Treachers by Sphericall predominance. Drunkards, Ly-
ars, and Adulterers by an inforc’d obedience of Planatary
inﬂuence; and all that we are euill in, by a diuine thru-
ſting on. An admirable euaſion of Whore-maſter-man,
to lay his Goatiſh diſpoſition on the charge of a Starre,
My father compounded with my mother vnder the Dra-
gons taile, and my Natiuity was vnder Vrſa Maior, ſo
that it followes, I am rough and Leacherous. I ſhould
haue bin that I am, had the maidenleſt Starre in the Fir-
mament twinkled on my baſtardizing.
Pat: he comes like the Cataſtrophe of the old Comedie:
my Cue is villanous Melancholly, with a ſighe like Tom
o’ Bedlam. — O theſe Eclipſes do portend theſe diui-
ſions. Fa, Sol, La, Me.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How now Brother Edmond, what ſerious con-
templation are you in?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I am thinking Brother of a prediƈtion I read this
other day, what ſhould follow theſe Eclipſes.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Do you buſie your ſelfe with that?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I promiſe you, the eﬀeƈts he writes of, ſucceede
vnhappily.
When ſaw you my Father laſt?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The night gone by.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Spake you with him?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I, two houres together.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Parted you in good termes? Found you no diſ-
pleaſure in him, by word, nor countenance?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: None at all,

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Bethink your ſelfe wherein you may haue oﬀen-
ded him: and at my entreaty forbeare his preſence, vntill
ſome little time hath qualiﬁed the heat of his diſpleaſure,
which at this inſtant ſo rageth in him, that with the miſ-
chiefe of your perſon, it would ſcarſely alay.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Some Villaine hath done me wrong.

speech.speaker: Edm.
speech.line: That’s my feare, I pray you haue a continent
forbearance till the ſpeed of his rage goes ſlower: and as
I ſay, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will
ﬁtly bring you to heare my Lord ſpeake: pray ye goe,
there’s my key: if you do ſtirre abroad, goe arm’d.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Arm’d, Brother?

speech.speaker: Edm.
speech.line: Brother, I aduiſe you to the beſt, I am no honeſt
man, if ther be any good meaning toward you: I haue told
you what I haue ſeene, and heard: But faintly. Nothing
like the image, and horror of it, pray you away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Shall I heare from you anon?

speech.speaker: Edm.
speech.line: I do ſerue you in this buſineſſe:
A Credulous Father, and a Brother Noble,
Whoſe nature is ſo farre from doing harmes,
That he ſuſpeƈts none: on whoſe fooliſh honeſtie
My praƈtiſes ride eaſie: I ſee the buſineſſe.
Let me, if not by birth, haue lands by wit,
All with me’s meete, that I can faſhion ﬁt.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Did my Father ſtrike my Gentleman for chi-
ding of his Foole?

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: By day and night, he wrongs me, euery howre
He ﬂaſhes into one groſſe crime, or other,
That ſets vs all at ods: Ile not endure it;
His Knights grow riotous, and himſelfe vpbraides vs
On euery triﬂe. When he returnes from hunting,
I will not ſpeake with him, ſay I am ſicke,
If you come ſlacke of former ſeruices,
You ſhall do well, the fault of it Ile anſwer.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: He’s comming Madam, I heare him.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Put on what weary negligence you pleaſe,
You and your Fellowes: I’de haue it come to queſtion;
If he diſtaſte it, let him to my Siſter,
Whoſe mind and mine I know in that are one,
Remember what I haue ſaid.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Well Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: And let his Knights haue colder lookes among
you: what growes of it no matter, aduiſe your fellowes
ſo, Ile write ſtraight to my Siſter to hold my courſe; pre-
pare for dinner.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If but as will I other accents borrow,
That can my ſpeech defuſe, my good intent
May carry through it ſelfe to that full iſſue
For which I raiz’d my likeneſſe. Now baniſht Kent,
If thou canſt ſerue where thou doſt ſtand condemn’d,
So may it come, thy Maſter whom thou lou’ſt,
Shall ﬁnd thee full of labours.

scene.stagedir: Hornes within. Enter Lear and Attendants.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me not ſtay a iot for dinner, go get it rea-
dy: how now, what art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A man Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What doſt thou profeſſe? What would’ſt thou
with vs?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I do profeſſe to be no leſſe then I ſeeme; to ſerue
him truely that will put me in truſt, to loue him that is
honeſt, to conuerſe with him that is wiſe and ſaies little, to
feare iudgement, to ﬁght when I cannot chooſe, and to
eate no ﬁſh.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A very honeſt hearted Fellow, and as poore as
the King.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If thou be’ſt as poore for a ſubieƈt, as hee’s for a
King, thou art poore enough. What wouldſt thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Seruice.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who wouldſt thou ſerue?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: You.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou know me fellow?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No Sir, but you haue that in your countenance,
which I would faine call Maſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Authority.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ſeruices canſt thou do?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I can keepe honeſt counſaile, ride, run, marre a
curious tale in telling it, and deliuer a plaine meſſage
bluntly: that which ordinary men are ﬁt for, I am qual-
liﬁed in, and the beſt of me, is Dilligence.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How old art thou?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Not ſo young Sir to loue a woman for ſinging,
nor ſo old to dote on her for any thing. I haue yeares on
my backe forty eight.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Follow me, thou ſhalt ſerue me, if I like thee no
worſe after dinner, I will not part from thee yet. Dinner
ho, dinner, where’s my knaue? my Foole? Go you and call
my Foole hither. You you Sirrah, where’s my Daughter?

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: So pleaſe you —

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ſaies the Fellow there? Call the Clot-
pole backe: wher’s my Foole? Ho, I thinke the world’s
aſleepe, how now? Where’s that Mungrell?

speech.speaker: Knigh.
speech.line: He ſaies my Lord, your Daughters is not well.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why came not the ſlaue backe to me when I
call’d him?

speech.speaker: Knigh.
speech.line: Sir, he anſwered me in the roundeſt manner, he
would not.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: He would not?

speech.speaker: Knight.
speech.line: My Lord, I know not what the matter is,
but to my iudgement your Highneſſe is not entertain’d
with that Ceremonious aﬀeƈtion as you were wont,
theres a great abatement of kindneſſe appeares as well in
the generall dependants, as in the Duke himſelfe also, and
your Daughter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha? Saiſt thou ſo?

speech.speaker: Knigh.
speech.line: I beſeech you pardon me my Lord, if I bee
miſtaken, for my duty cannot be ſilent, when I thinke
your Highneſſe wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou but remembreſt me of mine owne Con-
ception, I haue perceiued a moſt faint negleƈt of late,
which I haue rather blamed as mine owne iealous curio-
ſitie, then as a very pretence and purpoſe of vnkindneſſe;
I will looke further intoo’t: but where’s my Foole? I
haue not ſeene him this two daies.

speech.speaker: Knight.
speech.line: Since my young Ladies going into France
Sir, the Foole hath much pined away.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No more of that, I haue noted it well, goe you
and tell my Daughter, I would ſpeake with her. Goe you
call hither my Foole; Oh you Sir, you, come you hither
Sir, who am I Sir?

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: My Ladies Father.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My Ladies Father? my Lords knaue, you whor-
ſon dog, you ſlaue, you curre.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: I am none of theſe my Lord,
I beſeech your pardon.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do you bandy lookes with me, you Raſcall?

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Ile not be ſtrucken my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Nor tript neither, you baſe Foot-ball plaier.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I thanke thee fellow.
Thou ſeru’ſt me, and Ile loue thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Come ſir, ariſe, away, Ile teach you diﬀerences:
away, away, if you will meaſure your lubbers length a-
gaine, tarry, but away, goe too, haue you wiſedome, ſo.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Now my friendly knaue I thanke thee, there’s
earneſt of thy ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Let me hire him too, here’s my Coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How now my pretty knaue, how doſt thou?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sirrah, you were beſt take my Coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why my Boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why? for taking ones part that’s out of fauour,
nay, & thou canſt not ſmile as the wind ſits, thou’lt catch
colde ſhortly, there take my Coxcombe; why this fellow
ha’s baniſh’d two on’s Daughters, and did the third a
bleſſing againſt his will, if thou follow him, thou muſt
needs weare my Coxcombe. How now Nunckle? would
I had two Coxcombes and two Daughters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why my Boy?

speech.speaker: Fool.
speech.line: If I gaue them all my liuing, I’ld keepe my Cox-
combes my ſelfe, there’s mine, beg another of thy
Daughters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Take heed Sirrah, the whip.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Truth’s a dog muſt to kennell, hee muſt bee
whipt out, when the Lady Brach may ſtand by’th’ﬁre
and ſtinke.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A peſtilent gall to me.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Sirha, Ile teach thee a ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Marke it Nuncle;
Haue more then thou ſhoweſt,
Speake leſſe then thou knoweſt,
Lend leſſe then thou oweſt,
Ride more then thou goeſt,
Learne more then thou troweſt,
Set leſſe then thou throweſt;
Leaue thy drinke and thy whore,
And keepe in a dore,
And thou ſhalt haue more,
Then two tens to a ſcore.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: This is nothing Foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Then ’tis like the breath of an vnfeed Lawyer,
you gaue me nothing for’t, can you make no vſe of no-
thing Nuncle?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why no Boy,
Nothing can be made out of nothing.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prythee tell him, ſo much the rent of his land
comes to, he will not beleeue a Foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A bitter Foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou know the diﬀerence my Boy, be-
tweene a bitter Foole, and a ſweet one.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No Lad, teach me.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nunckle, giue me an egge, and Ile giue thee
two Crownes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What two Crownes ſhall they be?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why after I haue cut the egge i’th’ middle and
eate vp the meate, the two Crownes of the egge: when
thou cloueſt thy Crownes i’th’ middle, and gau’ſt away
both parts, thou boar’ſt thine Aſſe on thy backe o’re the
durt, thou hadſt little wit in thy bald crowne, when thou
gau’ſt thy golden one away; if I ſpeake like my ſelfe in
this, let him be whipt that ﬁrſt ﬁndes it ſo.
Fooles had nere leſſe grace in a yeere,
For wiſemen are growne foppiſh,
And know not how their wits to weare,
Their manners are ſo apiſh.

speech.speaker: Le.
speech.line: When were you wont to be ſo full of Songs ſirrah?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I haue vſed it Nunckle, ere ſince thou mad’ſt
thy Daughters thy Mothers, for when thou gau’ſt them
the rod, and put’ſt downe thine owne breeches, then they
For ſodaine ioy did weepe,
And I for ſorrow ſung,
That ſuch a King ſhould play bo-peepe,
And goe the Foole among.
Pry’thy Nunckle keepe a Schoolemaſter that can teach
thy Foole to lie, I would faine learne to lie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And you lie ſirrah, wee’l haue you whipt.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I maruell what kin thou and thy daughters are,
they’l haue me whipt for ſpeaking true: thou’lt haue me
whipt for lying, and ſometimes I am whipt for holding
my peace. I had rather be any kind o’ thing then a foole,
and yet I would not be thee Nunckle, thou haſt pared thy
wit o’ both ſides, and left nothing i’th’ middle; heere
comes one o’the parings.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How now Daughter? what makes that Frontlet
on? You are too much of late i’th’ frowne.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thou waſt a pretty fellow when thou hadſt no
need to care for her frowning, now thou art an O with-
out a ﬁgure, I am better then thou art now, I am a Foole,
thou art nothing. Yes forſooth I will hold my tongue, ſo
your face bids me, though you ſay nothing.
Mum, mum, he that keepes nor cruſt, nor crum,
Weary of all, ſhall want ſome. That’s a ſheal’d Peſcod.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Not only Sir this, your all-lycenc’d Foole,
But other of your inſolent retinue
Do hourely Carpe and Quarrell, breaking forth
In ranke, and (not to be endur’d) riots Sir.
I had thought by making this well knowne vnto you,
To haue found a ſafe redreſſe, but now grow fearefull
By what your ſelfe too late haue ſpoke and done,
That you proteƈt this courſe, and put it on
By your allowance, which if you ſhould, the fault
Would not ſcape cenſure, nor the redreſſes ſleepe,
Which in the tender of a wholeſome weale,
Mighty in their working do you that oﬀence,
Which elſe were ſhame, that then neceſſitie
Will call diſcreet proceeding.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: For you know Nunckle, the Hedge-Sparrow
fed the Cuckoo ſo long, that it’s had it head bit oﬀ by it
young, ſo out went the Candle, and we were left dark-
ling.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Are you our Daughter?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: I would you would make vſe of your good wiſedome
(Whereof I know you are fraught), and put away
Theſe diſpoſitions, which of late tranſport you
From what you rightly are.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: May not an Aſſe know, when the Cart drawes
the Horſe?
Whoop Iugge I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do’s any heere know me?
This is not Lear:
Do’s Lear walke thus? Speake thus? Where are his eies?
Either his Notion weakens, his Diſcernings
Are Lethargied. Ha! Waking? ’Tis not ſo?
Who is it that can tell me who I am?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Lears ſhadow.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Your name, faire Gentlewoman?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: This admiration Sir, is much o’th’ ſauour
Of other your new prankes. I do beſeech you
To vnderſtand my purpoſes aright:
As you are Old, and Reuerend, ſhould be Wiſe.
Heere do you keepe a hundred Knights and Squires,
Men ſo diſorder’d, ſo deboſh’d and bold,
That this our Court infeƈted with their manners,
Shewes like a riotous Inne; Epicuriſme and Luſt
Makes it more like a Tauerne, or a Brothell,
Then a grac’d Pallace. The ſhame it ſelfe doth ſpeake
For inſtant remedy. Be then deſir’d
By her, that elſe will take the thing ſhe begges,
A little to diſquantity your Traine,
And the remainders that ſhall ſtill depend,
To be ſuch men as may beſort your Age,
Which know themſelues, and you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Darkneſſe, and Diuels.
Saddle my horſes: call my Traine together.
Degenerate Baſtard, Ile not trouble thee;
Yet haue I left a daughter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: You ſtrike my people, and your diſorder’d rable,
make Seruants of their Betters.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Woe, that too late repents:
Is it your will, ſpeake Sir? Prepare my Horſes.
Ingratitude! thou Marble-hearted Fiend,
More hideous when thou ſhew’ſt thee in a Child,
Then the Sea-monſter.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Pray Sir be patient.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Deteſted Kite, thou lyeſt.
My Traine are men of choice, and rareſt parts,
That all particulars of dutie know,
And in the moſt exaƈt regard, ſupport
The worſhips of their name. O moſt ſmall fault,
How vgly did’ſt thou in Cordelia ſhew?
Which like an Engine, wrencht my frame of Nature
From the ﬁxt place: drew from my heart all loue,
And added to the gall. O Lear, Lear, Lear!
Beate at this gate that let thy Folly in,
And thy deere Iudgement out. Go, go, my people.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: My Lord, I am guiltleſſe, as I am ignorant
Of what hath moued you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: It may be ſo, my Lord.
Heare Nature, heare deere Goddeſſe, heare:
Suſpend thy purpoſe, if thou did’ſt intend
To make this Creature fruitfull:
Into her Wombe conuey ſtirrility,
Drie vp in her the Organs of increaſe,
And from her derogate body, neuer ſpring
A Babe to honor her. If ſhe muſt teeme,
Create her childe of Spleene, that it may liue
And be a thwart diſnatur’d torment to her.
Let it ſtampe wrinkles in her brow of youth,
With cadent Teares fret Channels in her cheekes,
Turne all her Mothers paines, and beneﬁts
To laughter, and contempt: That ſhe may feele,
How ſharper then a Serpents tooth it is,
To haue a thankleſſe Childe. Away, away.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Now Gods that we adore,
Whereof comes this?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Neuer aﬀliƈt your ſelfe to know more of it:
But let his diſpoſition haue that ſcope
As dotage giues it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ﬁftie of my Followers at a clap?
Within a fortnight?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: What’s the matter, Sir?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile tell thee:
Life and death, I am aſham’d
That thou haſt power to ſhake my manhood thus,
That theſe hot teares, which breake from me perforce
Should make thee worth them.
Blaſtes and Fogges vpon thee:
Th’ vntented woundings of a Fathers curſe
Pierce euerie ſenſe about thee. Old fond eyes,
Beweepe this cauſe againe, Ile plucke ye out,
And caſt you with the waters that you looſe
To temper Clay. Ha? Let it be ſo.
I haue another daughter,
Who I am ſure is kinde and comfortable:
When ſhe ſhall heare this of thee, with her nailes
Shee’l ﬂea thy Woluiſh viſage. Thou ſhalt ﬁnde,
That Ile reſume the ſhape which thou doſt thinke
I haue caſt oﬀ for euer.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Do you marke that?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: I cannot be ſo partiall Gonerill,
To the great loue I beare you.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Pray you content. What Oſwald, hoa?
You Sir, more Knaue then Foole, after your Maſter.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nunkle Lear, Nunkle Lear,
Tarry, take the Foole with thee:
A Fox, when one has caught her,
And ſuch a Daughter,
Should ſure to the Slaughter,
If my Cap would buy a Halter,
So the Foole followes after.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: This man hath had good Counſell,
A hundred Knights?
’Tis politike, and ſafe to let him keepe
At point a hundred Knights: yes, that on euerie dreame,
Each buz, each fancie, each complaint, diſlike,
He may enguard his dotage with their powres,
And hold our liues in mercy. Oſwald, I ſay.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Well, you may feare too farre.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Safer then truſt too farre;
Let me ſtill take away the harmes I feare,
Not feare ſtill to be taken. I know his heart,
What he hath vtter’d I haue writ my Siſter:
If ſhe ſuſtaine him, and his hundred Knights
When I haue ſhew’d th’ vnﬁtneſſe.
How now Oſwald?
What haue you writ that Letter to my Siſter?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Take you ſome company, and away to horſe,
Informe her full of my particular feare,
And thereto adde ſuch reaſons of your owne,
As may compaƈt it more. Get you gone,
And haſten your returne; no, no, my Lord,
This milky gentleneſſe, and courſe of yours
Though I condemne not, yet vnder pardon
You are much more at task for want of wiſedome,
Then prais’d for harmefull mildneſſe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: How farre your eies may pierce I cannot tell;
Striuing to better, oft we marre what’s well.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Nay then —

speech.speaker: Alb
speech.line: Well, well, th’ euent.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lear, Kent, Gentleman, and Foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Go you before to Gloſter with theſe Letters;
acquaint my Daughter no further with any thing you
know, then comes from her demand out of the Letter,
if your Dilligence be not ſpeedy, I ſhall be there afore
you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I will not ſleepe my Lord, till I haue deliuered
your Letter.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If a mans braines were in’s heeles, wert not in
danger of kybes?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I Boy.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Then I prythee be merry, thy wit ſhall not go
ſlip-ſhod.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Fool.
speech.line: Shalt ſee thy other Daughter will vſe thee kind-
ly, for though ſhe’s as like this, as a Crabbe’s like an
Apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What can’ſt tell Boy?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: She will taſte as like this as, a Crabbe do’s to a
Crab: thou canſt, tell why ones noſe ſtands i’th’ middle
on’s face?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why to keepe ones eyes of either ſide ’s noſe,
that what a man cannot ſmell out, he may ſpy into.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I did her wrong.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Can’ſt tell how an Oyſter makes his ſhell?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nor I neither; but I can tell why a Snaile ha’s
a houſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Why to put’s head in, not to giue it away to his
daughters, and leaue his hornes without a caſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I will forget my Nature, ſo kind a Father? Be
my Horſſes ready?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thy Aſſes are gone about ’em; the reaſon why
the ſeuen Starres are no mo then ſeuen, is a pretty reaſon.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Becauſe they are not eight.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Yes indeed, thou would’ſt make a good Foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To tak’t againe perforce; Monſter Ingratitude!

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: If thou wert my Foole Nunckle, Il’d haue thee
beaten for being old before thy time.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: How’s that?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Thou ſhouldſt not haue bin old, till thou hadſt
bin wiſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O let me not be mad, not mad ſweet Heauen:
keepe me in temper, I would not be mad. How now are
the Horſes ready?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Ready my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come Boy.

speech.speaker: Fool.
speech.line: She that’s a Maid now, & laughs at my departure,
Shall not be a Maid long, vnleſſe things be cut ſhorter.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Saue thee Curan.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: And you Sir, I haue bin
With your Father, and giuen him notice
That the Duke of Cornwall, and Regan his Ducheſſe
Will be here with him this night.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How comes that?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Nay I know not, you haue heard of the newes a-
broad, I meane the whiſper’d ones, for they are yet but
ear-kiſſing arguments.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Not I: pray you what are they?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Haue you heard of no likely Warres toward,
’Twixt the Dukes of Cornwall, and Albany?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Not a word.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: You may do then in time,
Fare you well Sir.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: The Duke be here to night? The better beſt,
This weaues it ſelfe perforce into my buſineſſe,
My Father hath ſet guard to take my Brother,
And I haue one thing of a queazie queſtion
Which I muſt aƈt, Briefeneſſe, and Fortune worke.
Brother, a word, diſcend; Brother I ſay,
My Father watches: O Sir, ﬂy this place,
Intelligence is giuen where you are hid;
You haue now the good aduantage of the night,
Haue you not ſpoken ’gainſt the Duke of Cornewall?
Hee’s comming hither, now i’th’ night, i’th’ haſte,
And Regan with him, haue you nothing ſaid
Vpon his partie ’gainſt the Duke of Albany?
Aduiſe your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I am ſure on’t, not a word.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I heare my Father comming, pardon me:
In cunning, I muſt draw my Sword vpon you:
Draw, ſeeme to defend your ſelfe,
Now quit you well.
Yeeld, come before my Father, light hoa, here,
Fly Brother, Torches, Torches, ſo farewell.
Some blood drawne on me, would beget opinion
Of my more ﬁerce endeauour. I haue ſeene drunkards
Do more then this in ſport; Father, Father,
Stop, ſtop, no helpe?

scene.stagedir: Enter Gloſter, and Seruants with Torches.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Now Edmund, where’s the villaine?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Here ſtood he in the dark, his ſharpe Sword out,
Mumbling of wicked charmes, coniuring the Moone
To ſtand auſpicious Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: But where is he?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Looke Sir, I bleed.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Where is the villaine, Edmund?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Fled this way Sir, when by no meanes he could.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Purſue him, ho: go after. By no meanes, what?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Perſwade me to the murther of your Lordſhip,
But that I told him the reuenging Gods,
’Gainſt Paricides did all the thunder bend,
Spoke with how manifold, and ſtrong a Bond
The Child was bound to’th’ Father; Sir in ﬁne,
Seeing how lothly oppoſite I ſtood
To his vnnaturall purpoſe, in fell motion
With his prepared Sword, he charges home
My vnprouided body, latch’d mine arme;
And when he ſaw my beſt alarum’d ſpirits
Bold in the quarrels right, rouz’d to th’ encounter,
Or whether gaſted by the noyſe I made,
Full ſodainely he ﬂed.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Let him ﬂy farre:
Not in this Land ſhall he remaine vncaught
And found; diſpatch, the Noble Duke my Maſter,
My worthy Arch and Patron comes to night,
By his authoritie I will proclaime it,
That he which ﬁnds him ſhall deſerue our thankes,
Bringing the murderous Coward to the ſtake:
He that conceales him death.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: When I diſſwaded him from his intent,
And found him pight to doe it, with curſt ſpeech
I threaten’d to diſcouer him; he replied,
Thou vnpoſſeſſing Baſtard, doſt thou thinke,
If I would ſtand againſt thee, would the repoſall
Of any truſt, vertue, or worth in thee
Make thy words faith’d? No, what ſhould I denie,
(As this I would, though thou didſt produce
My very Charaƈter) I’ld turne it all
To thy ſuggeſtion, plot, and damned praƈtiſe:
And thou muſt make a dullard of the world,
If they not thought the proﬁts of my death
Were very pregnant and potentiall ſpirits
To make thee ſeeke it.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: O ſtrange and faſtned Villaine,
Would he deny his Letter, ſaid he?
Harke, the Dukes Trumpets, I know not wher he comes;
All Ports Ile barre, the villaine ſhall not ſcape,
The Duke muſt grant me that: beſides, his piƈture
I will ſend farre and neere, that all the kingdome
May haue due note of him, and of my land,
(Loyall and naturall Boy) Ile worke the meanes
To make thee capable.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: How now my Noble friend, ſince I came hither
(Which I can call but now,) I haue heard ſtrangeneſſe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: If it be true, all vengeance comes too ſhort
Which can purſue th’ oﬀender; how doſt my Lord?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: O Madam, my old heart is crack’d, it’s crack’d.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What, did my Fathers Godſonne ſeeke your life?
He whom my Father nam’d, your Edgar?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: O Lady, Lady, ſhame would haue it hid.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Was he not companion with the riotous Knights
That tended vpon my Father?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I know not Madam, ’tis too bad, too bad.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Yes Madam, he was of that conſort.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: No maruaile then, though he were ill aﬀeƈted,
’Tis they haue put him on the old mans death,
To haue th’ expence and waſt of his Reuenues:
I haue this preſent euening from my Siſter
Beene well inform’d of them, and with ſuch cautions,
That if they come to ſoiourne at my houſe,
Ile not be there.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Nor I, aſſure thee Regan;
Edmund, I heare that you haue ſhewne your Father
A Child-like Oﬃce.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: It was my duty Sir.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: He did bewray his praƈtiſe, and receiu’d
This hurt you ſee, ſtriuing to apprehend him.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Is he purſued?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: If he be taken, he ſhall neuer more
Be fear’d of doing harme, make your owne purpoſe,
How in my ſtrength you pleaſe: for you Edmund,
Whoſe vertue and obedience doth this inſtant
So much commend it ſelfe, you ſhall be ours,
Nature’s of ſuch deepe truſt, we ſhall much need:
You we ﬁrſt ſeize on.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I ſhall ſerue you Sir truely, how euer elſe.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: For him I thanke your Grace.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: You know not why we came to viſit you?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Thus out of ſeaſon, thredding darke ey’d night,
Occaſions Noble Gloſter of ſome prize,
Wherein we muſt haue vſe of your aduiſe.
Our Father he hath writ, ſo hath our Siſter,
Of diﬀerences, which I beſt thought it ﬁt
To anſwere from our home: the ſeuerall Meſſengers
From hence attend diſpatch, our good old Friend,
Lay comforts to your boſome, and beſtow
Your needfull counſaile to our buſineſſes,
Which craues the inſtant vſe.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I ſerue you Madam,
Your Graces are right welcome.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Good dawning to thee Friend, art of this houſe?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Where may we ſet our horſes?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I’th’ myre.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Prythee, if thou lou’ſt me, tell me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I loue thee not.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Why then I care not for thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make
thee care for me.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Why do’ſt thou vſe me thus? I know thee not.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Fellow I know thee.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: What do’ſt thou know me for?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A Knaue, a Raſcall, an eater of broken meates, a
baſe, proud, ſhallow, beggerly, three-ſuited-hundred
pound, ﬁlthy wooſted-ſtocking knaue, a Lilly-liuered,
aƈtion-taking, whoreſon glaſſe-gazing ſuper-ſeruiceable
ﬁnicall Rogue, one Trunke-inheriting ſlaue, one that
would’ſt be a Baud in way of good ſeruice, and art no-
thing but the compoſition of a Knaue, Begger, Coward,
Pandar, and the Sonne and Heire of a Mungrill Bitch,
one whom I will beate into clamours whining, if thou
deny’ſt the leaſt ſillable of thy addition.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Why, what a monſtrous Fellow art thou, thus
to raile on one, that is neither knowne of thee, nor
knowes thee?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: What a brazen-fac’d Varlet art thou, to deny
thou knoweſt me? Is it two dayes ſince I tript vp thy
heeles, and beate thee before the King? Draw you rogue,
for though it be night, yet the Moone ſhines, Ile make a
ſop oth’ Moonſhine of you, you whoreſon Cullyenly
Barber-monger, draw.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Away, I haue nothing to do with thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Draw you Raſcall, you come with Letters a-
gainſt the King, and take Vanitie the puppets part, a-
gainſt the Royaltie of her Father: draw you Rogue, or
Ile ſo carbonado your ſhanks, draw you Raſcall, come
your waies.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Helpe, ho, murther, helpe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Strike you ſlaue: ſtand rogue, ſtand you neat
ſlaue, ſtrike.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Helpe hoa, murther, murther.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baſtard, Cornewall, Regan, Gloſter, Seruants.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter? Part.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: With you goodman Boy, if you pleaſe, come,
Ile ﬂeſh ye, come on yong Maſter.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Weapons? Armes? what’s the matter here?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Keepe peace vpon your liues, he dies that ſtrikes
againe, what is the matter?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: The Meſſengers from our Siſter, and the King?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What is your diﬀerence, ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I am ſcarce in breath my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No Maruell, you haue ſo beſtir’d your valour,
you cowardly Raſcall, nature diſclaimes in thee: a Taylor
made thee.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Thou art a ſtrange fellow, a Taylor make a man?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: A Taylor Sir, a Stone-cutter, or a Painter, could
not haue made him ſo ill, though they had bin but two
yeares oth’ trade.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Speake yet, how grew your quarrell?

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: This ancient Ruﬃan Sir, whoſe life I haue ſpar’d
at ſute of his gray-beard.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Thou whoreſon Zed, thou vnneceſſary letter:
my Lord, if you will giue me leaue, I will tread this vn-
boulted villaine into morter, and daube the wall of a
Iakes with him. Spare my gray-beard, you wagtaile?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Peace ſirrah,
You beaſtly knaue, know you no reuerence?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Yes Sir, but anger hath a priuiledge.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Why art thou angrie?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: That ſuch a ſlaue as this ſhould weare a Sword,
Who weares no honeſty: ſuch ſmiling rogues as theſe,
Like Rats oft bite the holy cords a twaine,
Which are t’ intrince, t’ vnlooſe: ſmooth euery paſſion
That in the natures of their Lords rebell,
Being oile to ﬁre, ſnow to the colder moodes,
Reuenge, aﬃrme, and turne their Halcion beakes
With euery gall, and varry of their Maſters,
Knowing naught (like dogges) but following:
A plague vpon your Epilepticke viſage,
Smoile you my ſpeeches, as I were a Foole?
Gooſe, if I had you vpon Sarum Plaine,
I’ld driue ye cackling home to Camelot.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: What art thou mad old Fellow?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: How fell you out, ſay that?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No contraries hold more antipathy,
Then I, and ſuch a knaue.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Why do’ſt thou call him Knaue?
What is his fault?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: His countenance likes me not.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: No more perchance do’s mine, nor his, nor hers.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir, ’tis my occupation to be plaine,
I haue ſeene better faces in my Time,
Then ſtands on any ſhoulder that I ſee
Before me, at this inſtant.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: This is ſome Fellow,
Who hauing beene prais’d for bluntneſſe, doth aﬀeƈt
A ſaucy roughnes, and conſtraines the garb
Quite from his Nature. He cannot ﬂatter he,
An honeſt mind and plaine, he muſt ſpeake truth,
And they will take it ſo, if not, hee’s plaine.
Theſe kind of Knaues I know, which in this plainneſſe
Harbour more craft, and more corrupter ends,
Then twenty ſilly-ducking obſeruants,
That ſtretch their duties nicely.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir, in good faith, in ſincere verity,
Vnder th’ allowance of your great aſpeƈt,
Whoſe inﬂuence like the wreath of radient ﬁre
On ﬂickring Phœbus front.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: What mean’ſt by this?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: To go out of my dialeƈt, which you diſcom-
mend ſo much; I know Sir, I am no ﬂatterer, he that be-
guild you in a plaine accent, was a plaine Knaue, which
for my part I will not be, though I ſhould win your
diſpleaſure to entreat me too’t.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: What was th’ oﬀence you gaue him?

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: I neuer gaue him any:
It pleas’d the King his Maſter very late
To ſtrike at me vpon his miſconſtruƈtion,
When he compaƈt, and ﬂattering his diſpleaſure
Tript me behind: being downe, inſulted, rail’d,
And put vpon him ſuch a deale of Man,
That worthied him, got praiſes of the King,
For him attempting, who was ſelfe-ſubdued,
And in the ﬂeſhment of this dead exploit,
Drew on me here againe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: None of theſe Rogues, and Cowards
But Aiax is there Foole.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Fetch forth the Stocks?
You ſtubborne ancient Knaue, you reuerent Bragart,
Wee’l teach you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir, I am too old to learne:
Call not your Stocks for me, I ſerue the King.
On whoſe imployment I was ſent to you,
You ſhall doe ſmall reſpeƈts, ſhow too bold malice
Againſt the Grace, and Perſon of my Maſter,
Stocking his Meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Fetch forth the Stocks;
As I haue life and Honour, there ſhall he ſit till Noone.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Till noone? till night my Lord, and all night too.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why Madam, if I were your Fathers dog,
You ſhould not vſe me ſo.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sir, being his Knaue, I will.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: This is a Fellow of the ſelfe ſame colour,
Our Siſter ſpeakes of. Come, bring away the Stocks.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Let me beſeech your Grace, not to do ſo,
The King his Maſter, needs muſt take it ill
That he ſo ſlightly valued in his Meſſenger,
Should haue him thus reſtrained.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Ile anſwere that.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: My Siſter may recieue it much more worſſe,
To haue her Gentleman abus’d, aſſaulted.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Come my Lord, away.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I am ſorry for thee friend, ’tis the Duke pleaſure,
Whoſe diſpoſition all the world well knowes
Will not be rub’d nor ſtopt, Ile entreat for thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Pray do not Sir, I haue watch’d and trauail’d hard,
Some time I ſhall ſleepe out, the reſt Ile whiſtle:
A good mans fortune may grow out at heeles:
Giue you good morrow.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: The Duke’s too blame in this,
’Twill be ill taken.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good King, that muſt approue the common ſaw,
Thou out of Heauens benediƈtion com’ſt
To the warme Sun.
Approach thou Beacon to this vnder Globe,
That by thy comfortable Beames I may
Peruſe this Letter. Nothing almoſt ſees miracles
But miſerie. I know ’tis from Cordelia,
Who hath moſt fortunately beene inform’d
Of my obſcured courſe. And ſhall ﬁnde time
From this enormous State, ſeeking to giue
Loſſes their remedies. All weary and o’re-watch’d,
Take vantage heauie eyes, not to behold
This ſhamefull lodging. Fortune goodnight,
Smile once more, turne thy wheele.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I heard my ſelfe proclaim’d,
And by the happy hollow of a Tree,
Eſcap’d the hunt. No Port is free, no place
That guard, and moſt vnuſall vigilance
Do’s not attend my taking. Whiles I may ſcape
I will preſerue myſelfe: and am bethought
To take the baſeſt, and moſt pooreſt ſhape
That euer penury in contempt of man,
Brought neere to beaſt; my face Ile grime with ﬁlth,
Blanket my loines, elſe all my haires in knots,
And with preſented nakedneſſe out-face
The Windes, and perſecutions of the skie;
The Country giues me proofe, and preſident
Of Bedlam beggers, who with roaring voices,
Strike in their num’d and mortiﬁed Armes.
Pins, Wodden-prickes, Nayles, Sprigs of Roſemarie:
And with this horrible obieƈt, from low Farmes,
Poore pelting Villages, Sheeps-Coates, and Milles,
Sometimes with Lunaticke bans, ſometime with Praiers
Inforce their charitie: poore Turlygod poore Tom,
That’s ſomething yet: Edgar I nothing am.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: ’Tis ſtrange that they ſhould ſo depart from home,
And not ſend backe my Meſſengers.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: As I learn’d,
The night before, there was no purpoſe in them
Of this remoue.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Haile to thee Noble Maſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha? Mak’ſt thou this ſhame thy paſtime?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No my Lord.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Hah, ha, he weares Cruell Garters Horſes are
tide by the heads, Dogges and Beares by’th’ necke,
Monkies by’th’ loynes, and Men by’th’ legs: when a man
ouerluſtie at legs, then he weares wodden nether-ſtocks.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What’s he,
That hath ſo much thy place miſtooke
To ſet thee heere?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: It is both he and ſhe,
Your Son, and Daughter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No I ſay.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I ſay yea.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: By Iupiter I ſweare no.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: By Iuno, I ſweare I.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: They durſt not do’t:
They could not, would not do’t: ’tis worſe then murther,
To do vpon reſpeƈt ſuch violent outrage:
Reſolue me with all modeſt haſte, which way
Thou might’ſt deſerue, or they impoſe this vſage,
Comming from vs.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: My Lord, when at their home
I did commend your Highneſſe Letters to them,
Ere I was riſen from the place, that ſhewed
My dutie kneeling, came there a reeking Poſte,
Stew’d in his haſte, halfe breathleſſe, painting forth
From Gonerill his Miſtris, ſalutations;
Deliuer’d Letters ſpight of intermiſſion,
Which preſently they read; on thoſe contents
They ſummon’d vp their meiney, ſtraight tooke Horſe,
Commanded me to follow, and attend
The leiſure of their anſwer, gaue me cold lookes,
And meeting heere the other Meſſenger,
Whoſe welcome I perceiu’d had poiſon’d mine,
Being the very fellow which of late
Diſplaid ſo ſawcily againſt your Highneſſe,
Hauing more man then wit about me, drew;
He rais’d the houſe, with loud and coward cries,
Your Sonne and Daughter found this treſpaſſe worth
The ſhame which heere it ſuﬀers.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Winters not gon yet, if the wil’d Geeſe ﬂy that way,
Fathers that weare rags, do make their Children blind,
But Fathers that beare bags, ſhall ſee their children kind.
Fortune that arrant whore, nere turns the key toth’ poore.
But for all this thou ſhalt haue as many Dolors for thy
Daughters, as thou canſt tell in a yeare.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Oh how this Mother ſwels vp toward my heart!
Hiſtorica paſſio, downe thou climing ſorrow,
Thy Elements below where is this Daughter?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: With the Earle Sir, here within.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Follow me not, ſtay here.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Made you no more oﬀence,
But what you ſpeake of?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: None:
How chance the King comes with ſo ſmall a number?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: And thou hadſt beene ſet i’th’ Stockes for that
queſtion, thoud’ſt well deſeru’d it.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Why Foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Wee’l ſet thee to ſchoole to an Ant, to teach
thee ther’s no labouring i’th’ winter. All that follow their
noſes, are led by their eyes, but blinde men, and there’s
not a noſe among twenty, but can ſmell him that’s ſtink-
ing; let go thy hold when a great wheele runs downe a
hill, leaſt it breake thy necke with following. But the
great one that goes vpward, let him draw thee after:
when a wiſeman giues thee better counſell giue me mine
againe, I would haue none but knaues follow it, ſince a
Foole giues it.
That Sir, which ſerues and ſeekes for gaine,
And followes but for forme;
Will packe, when it begins to raine,
And leaue thee in the ſtorme,
But I will tarry, the Foole will ſtay,
And let the wiſeman ﬂie:
The knaue turnes Foole that runnes away,
The Foole no knaue perdie.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Where learn’d you this Foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Not i’th’ Stocks Foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Deny to ſpeake with me?
They are ſicke, they are weary,
They haue trauail’d all the night? meere fetches,
The images of reuolt and ﬂying oﬀ.
Fetch me a better anſwer.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: My deere Lord,
You know the ﬁery quality of the Duke,
How vnremoueable and ﬁxt he is
In his owne courſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vengeance, Plague, Death, Confuſion:
Fiery? What quality? Why Gloſter, Gloſter,
I’ld ſpeake with the Duke of Cornewall, and his wife.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Well my good Lord, I haue inform’d them ſo.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Inform’d them? Do’ſt thou vnderſtand me man.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The King would ſpeake with Cornwall,
The deere Father
Would with his Daughter ſpeake, commands, tends, ſeruice,
Are they inform’d of this? My breath and blood:
Fiery? The fiery Duke, tell the hot Duke that —
No, but not yet, may be he is not well,
Inﬁrmity doth ſtill negleƈt all oﬃce,
Whereto our health is bound, we are not our ſelues,
When Nature being oppreſt, commands the mind
To ſuﬀer with the body; Ile forbeare,
And am fallen out with my more headier will,
To take the indiſpos’d and ſickly ﬁt,
For the ſound man. Death on my ſtate: wherefore
Should he ſit heere? This aƈt perſwades me,
That this remotion of the Duke and her
Is praƈtiſe only. Giue me my Seruant forth;
Goe tell the Duke, and’s wife, Il’d ſpeake with them:
Now, preſently: bid them come forth and heare me,
Or at their Chamber doore Ile beate the Drum,
Till it crie ſleepe to death.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I would haue all well betwixt you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Oh me my heart! My riſing heart! But downe.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Cry to it Nunckle, as the Cockney did to the
Eeles, when ſhe put ’em i’th’ Paſte aliue, ſhe knapt ’em
o’th’ coxcombs with a ſticke, and cryed downe wantons,
downe; ’twas her Brother, that in pure kindneſſe to his
Horſe buttered his Hay.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Good morrow to you both.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Haile to your Grace. Kent here ſet at liberty.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee your Highneſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Regan, I thinke you are. I know what reaſon
I haue to thinke ſo, if thou ſhould’ſt not be glad,
I would diuorce me from thy Mother Tombe,
Sepulchring an Adultreſſe. O are you free?
Some other time for that. Beloued Regan,
Thy Siſters naught: oh Regan, ſhe hath tied
Sharpe-tooth’d vnkindneſſe, like a vulture heere,
I can ſcarce ſpeake to thee, thou’lt not beleeue
With how deprau’d a quality. Oh Regan.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I pray you Sir, take patience, I haue hope
You leſſe know how to value her deſert,
Then ſhe to ſcant her dutie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Say? How is that?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I cannot thinke my Siſter in the leaſt
Would faile her Obligation. If Sir perchance
She haue reſtrained the Riots of your Followres,
’Tis on ſuch ground, and to ſuch wholeſome end,
As cleeres her from all blame.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My curſes on her.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: O Sir, you are old,
Nature in you ſtands on the very Verge
Of his conﬁne: you ſhould be rul’d, and led
By ſome diſcretion, that diſcernes your ſtate
Better then you your ſelfe: therefore I pray you,
That to our Siſter, you do make returne,
Say you haue wrong’d her.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Aske her forgiueneſſe?
Do you but marke how this becomes the houſe?
Deere daughter, I confeſſe that I am old;
Age is vnneceſſary: on my knees I begge,
That you’l vouchſafe me Rayment, Bed, and Food.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Good Sir, no more: theſe are vnſightly trickes:
Returne you to my Siſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Neuer Regan:
She hath abated me of halfe my Traine;
Look’d blacke vpon me, ſtrooke me with her Tongue
Moſt Serpent-like, vpon the very Heart.
All the ſtor’d Vengeances of Heauen, fall
On her ingratefull top: ſtrike her yong bones
You taking Ayres, with Lameneſſe.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Fye ſir, ﬁe.

speech.speaker: Le.
speech.line: You nimble Lightnings, dart your blinding ﬂames
Into her ſcornfull eyes: Infeƈt her Beauty,
You Fen-ſuck’d Fogges, drawne by the powrfull Sunne,
To fall, and bliſter.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: O the bleſt Gods!
So will you wiſh on me, when the raſh moode is on.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No Regan, thou ſhalt neuer haue my curſe:
Thy tender-hefted Nature ſhall not giue
Thee o’re to harſhneſſe: Her eyes are ﬁerce, but thine
Do comfort, and not burne. ’Tis not in thee
To grudge my pleaſures, to cut oﬀ my Traine,
To bandy haſty words, to ſcant my ſizes,
And in concluſion, to oppoſe the bolt
Againſt my comming in. Thou better know’ſt
The Oﬃces of Nature, bond of Childhood,
Eﬀeƈts of Curteſie, dues of Gratitude:
Thy halfe o’th’ Kingdome haſt thou not forgot,
Wherein I thee endow’d.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Good Sir, to’th’ purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who put my man i’th’ Stockes?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: What Trumpet’s that?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I know’t, my Siſters: this approues her Letter,
That ſhe would ſoone be heere. Is your Lady come?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This is a Slaue, whoſe eaſie borrowed pride
Dwels in the ſickly grace of her he followes.
Out Varlet, from my ſight.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: What meanes your Grace?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who ſtockt my Seruant? Regan, I haue good hope
Thou did’ſt not know on’t.
Who comes here? O Heauens!
If you do loue old men; if your ſweet ſway
Allow Obedience; if you your ſelues are old,
Make it your cauſe: Send downe, and take my part.
Art not aſham’d to looke vpon this Beard?
O Regan, will you take her by the hand?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Why not by’th’ hand Sir? How haue I oﬀended?
All’s not oﬀence that indiſcretion ﬁndes,
And dotage termes ſo.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O ſides, you are too tough!
Will you yet hold?
How came my man i’th’ Stockes?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I ſet him there, Sir: but his owne Diſorders
Deſeru’d much leſſe aduancement.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You? Did you?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I pray you Father being weake, ſeeme ſo.
If till the expiration of your Moneth
You will returne and ſoiourne with my Siſter,
Diſmiſſing halfe your traine, come then to me,
I am now from home, and out of that prouiſion
Which ſhall be needfull for your entertainement.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Returne to her? and ﬁfty men diſmiſs’d?
No, rather I abiure all roofes, and chuſe
To wage againſt the enmity oth’ ayre,
To be a Comrade with the Wolfe, and Owle,
Neceſſities ſharpe pinch. Returne with her?
Why the hot-bloodied France, that dowerleſſe tooke
Our yongeſt borne, I could as well be brought
To knee his Throne, and Squire-like penſion beg,
To keepe baſe life a foote; returne with her?
Perſwade me rather to be ſlaue and ſumpter
To this deteſted groome.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: At your choice Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I prythee Daughter do not make me mad,
I will not trouble thee my Child; farewell:
Wee’l no more meete, no more ſee one another.
But yet thou art my ﬂeſh, my blood, my Daughter,
Or rather a diſeaſe that’s in my ﬂeſh,
Which I muſt needs call mine. Thou art a Byle,
A plague ſore, or imboſſed Carbuncle
In my corrupted blood. But Ile not chide thee,
Let ſhame come when it will, I do not call it,
I do not bid the Thunder-bearer ſhoote,
Nor tell tales of thee to high-iudging Ioue,
Mend when thou can’ſt, be better at thy leiſure,
I can be patient, I can ſtay with Regan,
I and my hundred Knights.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Not altogether ſo,
I look’d not for you yet, nor am prouided
For your ﬁt welcome, giue eare Sir to my Siſter,
For thoſe that mingle reaſon with your paſſion,
Muſt be content to thinke you old, and ſo,
But ſhe knowes what ſhe doe’s.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Is this well ſpoken?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I dare auouch it Sir, what ﬁfty Followers?
Is it not well? What ſhould you need of more?
Yea, or ſo many? Sith that both charge and danger,
Speake ’gainſt ſo great a number? How in one houſe
Should many people, vnder two commands
Hold amity? ’Tis hard, almoſt impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Why might not you my Lord, receiue attendance
From thoſe that ſhe cals Seruants, or from mine?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Why not my Lord?
If then they chanc’d to ſlacke ye,
We could comptroll them; if you will come to me,
(For now I ſpie a danger) I entreate you
To bring but ﬁue and twentie, to no more
Will I giue place or notice.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I gaue you all.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And in good time you gaue it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Made you my Guardians, my Depoſitaries,
But kept a reſeruation to be followed
With ſuch a number? What, muſt I come to you
With ﬁue and twenty? Regan, ſaid you ſo?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And ſpeak’t againe my Lord, no more with me.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: Thoſe wicked Creatures yet do look wel fauor’d
When others are more wicked, not being the worſt
Stands in ſome ranke of praiſe, Ile go with thee,
Thy ﬁfty yet doth double ﬁue and twenty,
And thou art twice her Loue.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Heare me my Lord;
What need you ﬁue and twenty? Ten? Or ﬁue?
To follow in a houſe, where twice ſo many
Haue a command to tend you?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What need one?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O reaſon not the need: our baſeſt Beggers
Are in the pooreſt thing ſuperﬂuous.
Allow not Nature, more then Nature needs:
Mans life is cheape as Beaſtes. Thou art a Lady;
If onely to go warme were gorgeous,
Why Nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’ſt,
Which ſcarcely keepes thee warme, but for true need:
You Heauens, giue me that patience, patience I need,
You ſee me heere (you Gods) a poore old man,
As full of griefe as age, wretched in both,
If it be you that ſtirres theſe Daughters hearts
Againſt their Father, foole me not ſo much,
To beare it tamely: touch me with Noble anger,
And let not womens weapons, water drops,
Staine my mans cheekes. No you vnnaturall Hags,
I will haue ſuch reuenges on you both,
That all the world ſhall — I will do ſuch things,
What they are yet, I know not, but they ſhalbe
The terrors of the earth? you thinke Ile weepe,
No, Ile not weepe, I haue full cauſe of weeping.
But this heart ſhal break into a hundred thouſand ﬂawes
Or ere Ile weepe; O Foole, I ſhall go mad.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Let vs withdraw, ’twill be a Storme.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: This houſe is little, the old man and’s people,
Cannot be well beſtow’d.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: ’Tis his owne blame hath put himſelfe from reſt,
And muſt needs taſte his folly.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: For his particular, Ile receiue him gladly,
But not one follower.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: So am I purpos’d,
Where is my Lord of Gloſter?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Followed the old man forth, he is return’d.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: The King is in high rage.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Whether is he going?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: He cals to Horſe, but will I know not whether.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: ’Tis beſt to giue him way, he leads himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: My Lord, entreate him by no meanes to ſtay.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Alacke the night comes on, and the high windes
Do ſorely ruﬀle, for many Miles about
There’s ſcarce a Buſh.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: O Sir, to wilfull men,
The iniuries that they themſelues procure,
Muſt be their Schoole-Maſters: ſhut vp your doores,
He is attended with a deſperate traine,
And what they may incenſe him too, being apt,
To haue his eare abus’d, wiſedome bids feare.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Shut vp your doores my Lord, ’tis a wil’d night,
My Regan counſels well: come out oth’ ſtorme.
