scene.stagedir: Storme ſtill. Enter Kent, and a Gentleman, ſeuerally.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Who’s there beſides foule weather?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: One minded like the weather, moſt vnquietly.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I know you: Where’s the King?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Contending with the fretfull Elements;
Bids the winde blow the Earth into the Sea,
Or ſwell the curled Waters ’boue the Maine,
That things might change, or ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: But who is with him?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: None but the Foole, who labours to out-ieſt
His heart-ſtrooke iniuries.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sir, I do know you,
And dare vpon the warrant of my note
Commend a deere thing to you. There is diuiſion
(Although as yet the face of it is couer’d
With mutuall cunning) ’twixt Albany, and Cornwall:
Who haue, as who haue not, that their great Starres
Thron’d and ſet high; Seruants, who ſeeme no leſſe,
Which are to France the Spies and Speculations
Intelligent of our State. What hath bin ſeene,
Either in ſnuﬀes, and packings of the Dukes,
Or the hard Reine which both of them hath borne
Againſt the old kinde King; or ſomething deeper,
Whereof (perchance) theſe are but furniſhings.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I will talke further with you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No, do not:
For conﬁrmation that I am much more
Then my out-wall; open this Purſe, and take
What it containes. If you ſhall ſee Cordelia,
(As feare not but you ſhall) ſhew her this Ring,
And ſhe will tell you who that Fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fye on this Storme,
I will go ſeeke the King.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Giue me your hand,
Haue you no more to ſay?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Few words, but to eﬀeƈt more then all yet;
That when we haue found the King, in which your pain
That way, Ile this: He that ﬁrſt lights on him,
Holla the other.

scene.stagedir: Storme ſtill. Enter Lear, and Foole.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Blow windes, & crack your cheeks; Rage, blow
You Cataraƈts, and Hyrricano’s ſpout,
Till you haue drench’d our Steeples, drown the Cockes.
You Sulph’rous and Thought-executing Fires,
Vaunt-curriors of Oake-cleauing Thunder-bolts,
Sindge my white head. And thou all-ſhaking Thunder,
Strike ﬂat the thicke Rotundity o’th’ world,
Cracke Natures moulds, all germaines ſpill at once
That makes ingratefull Man.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: O Nunkle, Court holy-water in a dry houſe, is
better then this Rain-water out o’ doore. Good Nunkle,
in, aske thy Daughters bleſſing, heere’s a night pitties
neither Wiſemen, nor Fooles.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Rumble thy belly full: ſpit Fire, ſpowt Raine:
Nor Raine, Winde, Thunder, Fire are my Daughters;
I taxe not you, you Elements with vnkindneſſe.
I neuer gaue you Kingdome, call’d you Children;
You owe me no ſubſcription. Then let fall
Your horrible pleaſure. Heere I ſtand your Slaue,
A poore, inﬁrme, weake, and diſpis’d old man:
But yet I call you Seruile Miniſters,
That will with two pernicious Daughters ioyne
Your high-engender’d Battailes, ’gainſt a head
So old, and white as this. O, ho! ’tis foule.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: He that has a houſe to put’s head in, has a good
Head-peece:
The Codpiece that will houſe, before the head has any;
The Head, and he ſhall Lowſe: ſo Beggers marry many.
The man ý makes his Toe, what he his Hart ſhold make,
Shall of a Corne cry woe, and turne his ſleepe to wake.
For there was neuer yet faire woman, but ſhee made
mouthes in a glaſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, I will be the patterne of all patience,
I will ſay nothing.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Marry here’s Grace, and a Codpiece, that’s a
Wiſeman, and a Foole.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alas Sir are you here? Things that loue night,
Loue not ſuch nights as theſe: The wrathfull Skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the darke
And make them keepe their Caues: Since I was man,
Such ſheets of Fire, ſuch burſts of horrid Thunder,
Such groanes of roaring Winde, and Raine, I neuer
Remember to haue heard. Mans Nature cannot carry
Th’ aﬀliƈtion, nor the feare.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let the great Goddes
That keepe this dreadfull pudder o’re our heads,
Finde out their enemies now. Tremble thou Wretch,
That haſt within thee vndivulged Crimes
Vnwhipt of Iuſtice. Hide thee, thou Bloudy hand;
Thou Periur’d, and thou Simular of Vertue
That art Inceſtuous. Caytiﬀe, to peeces ſhake
That vnder couert, and conuenient ſeeming
Ha’s praƈtis’d on mans life. Cloſe pent-vp guilts,
Riue your concealing Continents, and cry
Theſe dreadfull Summoners grace. I am a man,
More ſinn’d againſt, then ſinning.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alacke, bare-headed?
Gracious my Lord, hard by heere is a Houell,
Some friendſhip will it lend you ’gainſt the Tempeſt:
Repoſe you there, while I to this hard houſe,
(More harder then the ſtones whereof ’tis rais’d,
Which euen but now, demanding after you,
Deny’d me to come in) returne, and force
Their ſcanted curteſie.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My wits begin to turne.
Come on my boy. How doſt my boy? Art cold?
I am cold my ſelfe. Where is this ſtraw, my Fellow?
The Art of our Neceſſities is ſtrange,
And can make vilde things precious. Come, your Houel;
Poore Foole, and Knaue, I haue one part in my heart
That’s ſorry yet for thee.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: He that has and a little-tyne wit,
With heigh-ho, the Winde and the Raine,
Muſt make content with his Fortunes ﬁt,
Though the Raine it raineth euery day.

speech.speaker: Le.
speech.line: True Boy: Come bring vs to this Houell.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: This is a braue night to coole a Curtizan:
Ile ſpeake a Propheſie ere I go:
When Prieſts are more in word, then matter;
When Brewers marre their Malt with water;
When Nobles are their Taylors Tutors,
No Heretiques burn’d, but wenches Sutors;
When euery Caſe in Law, is right;
No Squire in debt, nor no poore Knight;
When Slanders do not liue in Tongues;
Nor Cut-purſes come not to throngs;
When Vſurers tell their Gold i’th’ Field,
And Baudes, and whores, do Churches build,
Then ſhal the Realme of Albion, come to great confuſion:
Then comes the time, who liues to ſee’t,
That going ſhalbe vs’d with feet.
This prophecie Merlin ſhall make, for I liue before his time.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Alacke, alacke Edmund, I like not this vnnaturall
dealing; when I deſired their leaue that I might pity him,
they tooke from me the vſe of mine owne houſe, charg’d
me on paine of perpetuall diſpleaſure, neither to ſpeake
of him, entreat for him, or any way ſuſtaine him.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Moſt ſauage and vnnaturall.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Go too; ſay you nothing. There is diuiſion be-
tweene the Dukes, and a worſſe matter then that: I haue
receiued a Letter this night, ’tis dangerous to be ſpoken,
I haue lock’d the Letter in my Cloſſet, theſe iniuries the
King now beares, will be reuenged home; ther is part of
a Power already footed, we muſt incline to the King, I
will looke him, and priuily relieue him; goe you and
maintaine talke with the Duke, that my charity be not of
him perceiued; If he aske for me, I am ill, and gone to
bed, if I die for it, (as no leſſe is threatned me) the King
my old Maſter muſt be relieued. There is ſtrange things
toward Edmund, pray you be carefull.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: This Curteſie forbid thee, ſhall the Duke
Inſtantly know, and of that Letter too;
This ſeemes a faire deſeruing, and muſt draw me
That which my Father looſes: no leſſe then all,
The yonger riſes, when the old doth fall.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter,
The tirrany of the open night’s too rough
For Nature to endure. Storme ſtill

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me alone.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord enter heere.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Wilt breake my heart?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I had rather breake mine owne,
Good my Lord enter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou think’ſt ’tis much that this contentious ſtorme
Inuades vs to the skin ſo: ’tis to thee,
But where the greater malady is ﬁxt,
The leſſer is ſcarce felt. Thou’dſt ſhun a Beare,
But if thy ﬂight lay toward the roaring Sea,
Thou’dſt meete the Beare i’th’ mouth, when the mind’s free,
The bodies delicate: the tempeſt in my mind,
Doth from my ſences take all feeling elſe,
Saue what beates there, Filliall ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth ſhould teare this hand
For lifting food too’t? But I will puniſh home;
No, I will weepe no more; in ſuch a night,
To ſhut me out? Poure on, I will endure:
In ſuch a night as this? O Regan, Gonerill,
Your old kind Father, whoſe franke heart gaue all,
O that way madneſſe lies, let me ſhun that:
No more of that.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord enter here.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Prythee go in thy ſelfe, ſeeke thine owne eaſe,
This tempeſt will not giue me leaue to ponder
On things would hurt me more, but Ile goe in,
In Boy, go ﬁrſt. You houſeleſſe pouertie,
Nay get thee in; Ile pray, and then Ile ſleepe.
Poore naked wretches, where ſo ere you are
That bide the pelting of this pittileſſe ſtorme,
How ſhall your Houſe-leſſe heads, and vnfed ſides,
Your lop’d, and window’d raggedneſſe defend you
From ſeaſons ſuch as theſe? O I haue tane
Too little care of this: Take Phyſicke, Pompe,
Expoſe thy ſelfe to feele what wretches feele,
That thou maiſt ſhake the ſuperﬂux to them,
And ſhew the Heauens more iuſt.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Fathom, and halfe, Fathom and halfe; poore Tom.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Come not in heere Nuncle, here’s a ſpirit, helpe
me, helpe me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Giue my thy hand, who’s there?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: A ſpirite, a ſpirite, he ſayes his name’s poore
Tom.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: What art thou that doſt grumble there i’th’
ſtraw? Come forth.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Away, the foule Fiend followes me, through the
ſharpe Hauthorne blow the windes. Humh, goe to thy
bed and warme thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Did’ſt thou giue all to thy Daughters? And art
thou come to this?

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: Who giues any thing to poore Tom? Whom
the foule ﬁend hath led through Fire, and through Flame,
through Sword, and Whirle-Poole, o’re Bog, and Quag-
mire, that hath laid Kniues vnder his Pillow, and Halters
in his Pue, ſet Rats-bane by his Porredge, made him
Proud of heart, to ride on a Bay trotting Horſe, ouer foure
incht Bridges, to courſe his owne ſhadow for a Traitor.
Bliſſe thy ﬁue Wits, Toms a cold. O do, de, do, de, do, de,
bliſſe thee from Whirle-Windes, Starre-blaſting, and ta-
king, do poore Tom ſome charitie, whom the foule Fiend
vexes. There could I haue him now, and there, and there
againe, and there.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha’s his Daughters brought him to this paſſe?
Could’ſt thou ſaue nothing? Would’ſt thou giue ’em all?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nay, he reſeru’d a Blanket, elſe we had bin all
ſham’d.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous ayre
Hang fated o’re mens faults, light on thy Daughters.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: He hath no Daughters Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Death Traitor, nothing could haue ſubdu’d Nature
To ſuch a lowneſſe, but his vnkind Daughters.
Is it the faſhion, that diſcarded Fathers,
Should haue thus little mercy on their ﬂeſh:
Iudicious puniſhment, ’twas this ﬂeſh begot
Thoſe Pelicane Daughters.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Pillicock ſat on Pillicock hill, alow: alow, loo, loo.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: This cold night will turne vs all to Fooles, and
Madmen.

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: Take heed o’th’ foule Fiend, obey thy Pa-
rents, keepe thy words Iuſtice, ſweare not, commit not,
with mans ſworne Spouſe: ſet not thy Sweet-heart on
proud array. Tom’s a cold.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What haſt thou bin?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: A Seruingman? Proud in heart, and minde; that
curl’d my haire, wore Gloues in my cap; ſeru’d the Luſt
of my Miſtris heart, and did the aƈte of darkeneſſe with
her. Swore as many Oathes, as I ſpake words, & broke
them in the ſweet face of Heauen. One, that ſlept in the
contriuing of Luſt, and wak’d to doe it. Wine lou’d I
deerely, Dice deerely; and in Woman, out-Paramour’d
the Turke. Falſe of heart, light of eare, bloody of hand;
Hog in ſloth, Foxe in ſtealth, Wolfe in greedineſſe, Dog
in madnes, Lyon in prey. Let not the creaking of ſhooes,
Nor the ruſtling of Silkes, betray thy poore heart to wo-
man. Keepe thy foote out of Brothels, thy hand out of
Plackets, thy pen from Lenders Bookes, and defye the
foule Fiend. Still through the Hauthorne blowes the
cold winde: Sayes ſuum, mun, nonny, Dolphin my Boy,
Boy Seſey: let him trot by.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thou wert better in a Graue, then to anſwere
with thy vncouer’d body, this extremitie of the Skies. Is
man no more then this? Conſider him well. Thou ow’ſt
the Worme no Silke; the Beaſt, no Hide; the Sheepe, no
Wooll; the Cat, no perfume. Ha? Here’s three on’s are
ſophiſticated. Thou art the thing it ſelfe; vnaccommo-
dated man, is no more but ſuch a poore, bare, forked A-
nimall as thou art. Oﬀ, oﬀ you Lendings: Come, vn-
button heere.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prythee Nunckle be contented, ’tis a naughtie
night to ſwimme in. Now a little ﬁre in a wilde Field,
were like an old Letchers heart, a ſmall ſpark, all the reſt
on’s body, cold: Looke, heere comes a walking ﬁre.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This is the foule Flibbertigibbet; hee begins at
Curfew, and walkes at ﬁrſt Cocke: Hee giues the Web
and the Pin, ſquints the eye, and makes the Hare-lippe;
Mildewes the white Wheate, and hurts the poore Crea-
ture of earth.
Swithold footed thrice the old,
He met the Night-Mare, and her nine-fold;
Bid her a-light, and her troth-plight,
And aroynt thee Witch, aroynt thee.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: How fares your Grace?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What’s he?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Who’s there? What is’t you ſeeke?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: What are you there? Your Names?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Tom, that eates the ſwimming Frog, the
Toad, the Tod-pole, the wall-Neut, and the water: that
in the furie of his heart, when the foule Fiend rages, eats
Cow-dung for Sallets; ſwallowes the old Rat, and the
ditch-Dogge; drinkes the green Mantle of the ſtanding
Poole: who is whipt from Tything to Tything, and
ſtockt, puniſh’d, and impriſon’d: who hath three Suites
to his backe, ſixe ſhirts to his body:
Horſe to ride, and weapon to weare:
But Mice, and Rats, and ſuch ſmall Deare,
Haue bin Toms food, for ſeuen long yeare:
Beware my Follower. Peace Smulkin, peace thou Fiend.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: What, hath your Grace no better company?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The Prince of Darkeneſſe is a Gentleman. Modo
he’s call’d, and Mahu.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Our ﬂeſh and blood, my Lord, is growne ſo
vilde, that it doth hate what gets it.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Tom’s a cold.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Go in with me; my duty cannot ſuﬀer
T’ obey in all your daughters hard commands:
Though their Iniunƈtion be to barre my doores,
And let this Tyrannous night take hold vpon you,
Yet haue I ventured to come ſeeke you out,
And bring you where both ﬁre, and food is ready.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Firſt let me talke with this Philoſopher,
What is the cauſe of Thunder?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord take his oﬀer,
Go into th’ houſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile talke a word with this ſame lerned Theban:
What is your ſtudy?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How to preuent the Fiend, and to kill Vermine.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me aske you one word in priuate.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Importune him once more to go my Lord,
His wits begin t’ vnſettle.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Canſt thou blame him? Storm ſtill
His Daughters ſeeke his death: Ah, that good Kent,
He ſaid it would be thus: poore baniſh’d man:
Thou ſayeſt the King growes mad, Ile tell thee Friend
I am almoſt mad my ſelfe. I had a Sonne,
Now out-law’d from my blood: he ſought my life
But lately: very late: I lou’d him (Friend)
No Father his Sonne deerer: true to tell thee,
The greefe hath craz’d my wits. What a night’s this?
I do beſeech your grace.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O cry you mercy, Sir:
Noble Philoſopher, your company.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tom’s a cold.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: In fellow there, into th’ Houel; keep thee warm.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come, let’s in all.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: This way, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: With him;
I will keepe ſtill with my Philoſopher.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Good my Lord, ſooth him:
Let him take the Fellow.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Take him you on.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Sirra, come on: go along with vs.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Come, good Athenian.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: No words, no words, huſh.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Childe Rowland to the darke Tower came,
His word was ſtill, ﬁe, foh, and fumme,
I ſmell the blood of a Brittiſh man.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I will haue my reuenge, ere I depart his houſe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How my Lord, I may be cenſured, that Nature
thus giues way to Loyaltie, ſomething feares mee to
thinke of.

speech.speaker: Cornw.
speech.line: I now perceiue, it was not altogether your
Brothers euill diſpoſition made him ſeeke his death: but
a prouoking merit ſet a-worke by a reprouable badneſſe
in himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: How malicious is my fortune, that I muſt re-
pent to be iuſt? This is the Letter which hee ſpoake of;
which approues him an intelligent partie to the aduanta-
ges of France. O Heauens! that this Treaſon were not;
or not I the deteƈtor.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Go with me to the Dutcheſſe.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If the matter of this Paper be certain, you haue
mighty buſineſſe in hand.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: True or falſe, it hath made thee Earle of Glou-
ceſter: ſeeke out where thy Father is, that hee may bee
ready for our apprehenſion.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: If I ﬁnde him comforting the King, it will ſtuﬀe
his ſuſpition more fully. I will perſeuer in my courſe of
Loyalty, though the conﬂiƈt be ſore betweene that, and
my blood.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I will lay truſt vpon thee: and thou ſhalt ﬁnde
a deere Father in my loue.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Heere is better then the open ayre, take it thank-
fully: I will peece out the comfort with what addition I
can: I will not be long from you.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: All the powre of his wits, haue giuen way to his
impatience: the Gods reward your kindneſſe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Fraterretto cals me, and tells me Nero is an Ang-
ler in the Lake of Darkneſſe: pray Innocent, and beware
the foule Fiend.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Prythee Nunkle tell me, whether a madman be
a Gentleman, or a Yeoman.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A King, a King.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: No, he’s a Yeoman, that ha’s a Gentleman to
his Sonne: for hee’s a mad Yeoman that ſees his Sonne a
Gentleman before him.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To haue a thouſand with red burning ſpits
Come hizzing in vpon ’em.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Bleſſe thy ﬁue wits.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: O pitty: Sir, where is the patience now
That you ſo oft haue boaſted to retaine?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: My teares begin to take his part ſo much,
They marre my counterfetting.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The little dogges, and all;
Trey, Blanch, and Sweet-heart: ſee, they barke at me.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Tom, will throw his head at them: Auaunt you
Curres, be thy mouth or blacke or white:
Tooth that poyſons if it bite:
Maſtiﬀe, Grey-hound, Mongrill, Grim,
Hound or Spaniell, Brache, or Hym:
Or Bobtaile tight, or Troudle taile,
Tom will make him weepe and waile,
For with throwing thus my head;
Dogs leapt the hatch, and all are ﬂed.
Do, de, de, de: ſeſe: Come, march to Wakes and Fayres,
And Market Townes: poore Tom thy horne is dry,

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then let them Anatomize Regan: See what
breeds about her heart. Is there any cauſe in Nature that
make theſe hard-hearts. You ſir, I entertaine for one of
my hundred; only, I do not like the faſhion of your gar-
ments. You will ſay they are Perſian; but let them bee
chang’d.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Now good my Lord, lye heere, and reſt awhile.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Make no noiſe, make no noiſe, draw the Cur-
taines: ſo, ſo, wee’l go to Supper i’th’ morning.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: And Ile go to bed at noone.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Come hither Friend:
Where is the King my Maſter?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Here Sir, but trouble him not, his wits are gon.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Good friend, I prythee take him in thy armes;
I haue ore-heard a plot of death vpon him:
There is a Litter ready, lay him in’t,
And driue toward Douer friend, where thou ſhalt meete
Both welcome, and proteƈtion. Take vp thy Maſter,
If thou ſhould’ſt dally halfe an houre, his life
With thine, and all that oﬀer to defend him,
Stand in aſſured loſſe. Take vp, take vp,
And follow me, that will to ſome prouiſion
Giue thee quicke conduƈt. Come, come, away.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cornwall, Regan, Gonerill, Baſtard, and Seruants.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Poſte ſpeedily to my Lord your husband, ſhew
him this Letter, the Army of France is landed: ſeeke out
the Traitor Glouſter.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Hang him inſtantly.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Plucke out his eyes.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Leaue him to my diſpleaſure. Edmond, keepe
you our Siſter company: the reuenges wee are bound to
take vppon your Traitorous Father, are not ﬁt for your
beholding. Aduice the Duke where you are going, to a
moſt feſtinate preparation: we are bound to the like. Our
Poſtes ſhall be ſwift, and intelligent betwixt vs. Fare-
well deere Siſter, farewell my Lord of Glouſter.
How now? Where’s the King?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: My Lord of Glouſter hath conuey’d him hence
Some ﬁue or ſix and thirty of his Knights
Hot Queſtriſts after him, met him at gate,
Who, with ſome other of the Lords, dependants,
Are gone with him toward Douer; where they boaſt
To haue well armed Friends.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Get horſes for your Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Farewell ſweet Lord, and Siſter.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Edmund farewell: go ſeek the Traitor Gloſter,
Pinnion him like a Theefe, bring him before vs:
Though well we may not paſſe vpon his life
Without the forme of Iuſtice: yet our power
Shall do a curt’ſie to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not comptroll.
Who’s there? the Traitor?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Ingratefull Fox, ’tis he.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Binde faſt his corky armes.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: What meanes your Graces?
Good my Friends conſider you are my Gheſts:
Do me no foule play, Friends.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Binde him I ſay.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Hard, hard: O ﬁlthy Traitor.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Vnmercifull Lady, as you are, I’me none.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: To this Chaire binde him,
Villaine, thou ſhalt ﬁnde.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: By the kinde Gods, ’tis moſt ignobly done
To plucke me by the Beard.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: So white, and ſuch a Traitor?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Naughty Ladie,
Theſe haires which thou doſt rauiſh from my chin
Will quicken and accuſe thee. I am your Hoſt,
With Robbers hands, my hoſpitable fauours
You ſhould not ruﬀle thus. What will you do?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Come Sir.
What Letters had you late from France?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Be ſimple anſwer’d, for we know the truth.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: And what confederacie haue you with the Trai-
tors, late footed in the Kingdome?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: To whoſe hands
You haue ſent the Lunaticke King: Speake.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I haue a Letter gueſſingly ſet downe
Which came from one that’s of a newtrall heart,
And not from one oppos’d.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Cunning.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: And falſe.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Where haſt thou ſent the King?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: To Douer.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer?
Was’t thou not charg’d at perill.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer? Let him anſwer that.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I am tyed to’th’ Stake,
And I muſt ſtand the Courſe.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Wherefore to Douer?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Becauſe I would not ſee thy cruell Nailes
Plucke out his poore old eyes: nor thy ﬁerce Siſter,
In his Annointed ﬂeſh, ſticke boariſh phangs.
The Sea, with ſuch a ſtorme as his bare head,
In Hell-blacke-night indur’d, would haue buoy’d vp
And quench’d the Stelled ﬁres:
Yet poore old heart, he holpe the Heauens to raine.
If Wolues had at thy Gate howl’d that ſterne time,
Thou ſhould’ſt haue ſaid, good Porter turne the Key:
All Cruels elſe ſubſcribe: but I ſhall ſee
The winged Vengeance ouertake ſuch Children.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: See’t ſhalt thou neuer. Fellowes hold ý Chaire,
Vpon theſe eyes of thine, Ile ſet my foote.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: He that will thinke to liue, till he be old,
Giue me ſome helpe. — O cruell! O you Gods.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: One ſide will mocke another: Th’ other too.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: If you ſee vengeance.

speech.speaker: Seru.
speech.line: Hold your hand, my Lord:
I haue ſeru’d you euer ſince I was a Childe:
But better ſeruice haue I neuer done you,
Then now to bid you hold.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: How now, you dogge?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: If you did weare a beard vpon your chin,
I’ld ſhake it on this quarrell. What do you meane?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: My Villaine?

speech.speaker: Seru.
speech.line: Nay then come on, and take the chance of anger.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Giue me thy Sword. A pezant ſtand vp thus?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Oh I am ſlaine: my Lord, you haue one eye left
To ſee ſome miſchefe on him. Oh.

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: Leſt it ſee more, preuent it; Out vilde gelly:
Where is thy luſter now?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: All darke and comfortleſſe?
Where’s my Sonne Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the ſparkes of Nature
To quit this horrid aƈte.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Out treacherous Villaine,
Thou call’ſt on him, that hates thee. It was he
That made the ouerture of thy Treaſons to vs:
Who is too good to pitty thee.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: O my Follies! then Edgar was abus’d,
Kinde Gods, forgiue me that, and proſper him.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Go thruſt him out at gates, and let him ſmell
His way to Douer. Exit with Glouſter.
How is’t my Lord? How looke you?

speech.speaker: Corn.
speech.line: I haue receiu’d a hurt: Follow me Lady;
Turne out that eyeleſſe Villaine: throw this Slaue
Vpon the Dunghill: Regan, I bleed apace,
Vntimely comes this hurt. Giue me your arme.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Yet better thus, and knowne to be contemn’d,
Then ſtill contemn’d and ﬂatter’d, to be worſt:
The loweſt, and moſt deieƈted thing of Fortune,
Stands ſtill in eſperance, liues not in feare:
The lamentable change is from the beſt,
The worſt returnes to laughter. Welcome then,
Thou vnſubſtantiall ayre that I embrace:
The Wretch that thou haſt blowne vnto the worſt,
Owes nothing to thy blaſts.
But who comes heere? My Father poorely led?
World, World, O world!
But that thy ſtrange mutations make vs hate thee,
Life would not yeelde to age.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: O my good Lord, I haue bene your Tenant,
And your Fathers Tenant, theſe foureſcore yeares.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Away, get thee away: good Friend be gone,
Thy comforts can do me no good at all,
Thee, they may hurt.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: You cannot ſee your way.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I haue no way, and therefore want no eyes:
I ſtumbled when I ſaw. Full oft ’tis ſeene,
Our meanes ſecure vs, and our meere defeƈts
Proue our Commodities. Oh deere Sonne Edgar,
The food of thy abuſed Fathers wrath:
Might I but liue to ſee thee in my touch,
I’ld ſay I had eyes againe.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: How now? who’s there?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O Gods! Who is’t can ſay I am at the worſt?
I am worſe then ere I was.

speech.speaker: Old.
speech.line: ’Tis poore mad Tom.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: And worſe I may be yet: the worſt is not,
So long as we can ſay this is the worſt.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Fellow, where goeſt?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Is it a Beggar-man?

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Madman, and beggar too.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: He has ſome reaſon, elſe he could not beg.
I’th’ laſt nights ſtorme, I ſuch a fellow ſaw;
Which made me thinke a Man, a Worme. My Sonne
Came then into my minde, and yet my minde
Was then ſcarſe Friends with him.
I haue heard more ſince:
As Flies to wanton Boyes, are we to th’ Gods,
They kill vs for their ſport.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: How ſhould this be?
Bad is the Trade that muſt play Foole to ſorrow,
Ang’ring it ſelfe, and others. Bleſſe thee Maſter.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Is that the naked Fellow?

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: I, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Get thee away: If for my ſake
Thou wilt ore-take vs hence a mile or twaine
I’th’ way toward Douer, do it for ancient loue,
And bring ſome couering for this naked Soule,
Which Ile intreate to leade me.

speech.speaker: Old.
speech.line: Alacke ſir, he is mad.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: ’Tis the times plague,
When Madmen leade the blinde:
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleaſure:
Aboue the reſt, be gone.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Ile bring him the beſt Parrell that I haue
Come on’t what will.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Sirrah, naked fellow.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Poore Tom’s a cold. I cannot daub it further.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Come hither fellow.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: And yet I muſt:
Bleſſe thy ſweete eyes, they bleede.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Know’ſt thou the way to Douer?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Both ſtyle, and gate; Horſeway, and foot-path:
poore Tom hath bin ſcarr’d out of his good wits. Bleſſe
thee good mans ſonne, from the foule Fiend.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Here take this purſe, ӳ whom the heau’ns plagues
Haue humbled to all ſtrokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: Heauens deale ſo ſtill:
Let the ſuperﬂuous, and Luſt-dieted man,
That ſlaues your ordinance, that will not ſee
Becauſe he do’s not feele, feele your powre quickly:
So diſtribution ſhould vndoo exceſſe,
And each man haue enough. Doſt thou know Douer?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I Maſter.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: There is a Cliﬀe, whoſe high and bending head
Lookes fearfully in the conﬁned Deepe:
Bring me but to the very brimme of it,
And Ile repayre the miſery thou do’ſt beare
With ſomething rich about me: from that place,
I ſhall no leading neede.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me thy arme;
Poore Tom ſhall leade thee.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Welcome my Lord. I meruell our mild husband
Not met vs on the way. Now, where’s your Maſter?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam within, but neuer man ſo chang’d:
I told him of the Army that was Landed:
He ſmil’d at it. I told him you were comming,
His anſwer was, the worſe. Of Gloſters Treachery,
And of the loyall Seruice of his Sonne
When I inform’d him, then he call’d me Sot,
And told me I had turn’d the wrong ſide out:
What moſt he ſhould diſlike, ſeemes pleaſant to him;
What like, oﬀenſiue.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Then ſhall you go no further.
It is the Cowiſh terror of his ſpirit
That dares not vndertake: Hee’l not feele wrongs
Which tye him to an anſwer: our wiſhes on the way
May proue eﬀeƈts. Backe Edmond to my Brother,
Haſten his Muſters, and conduƈt his powres.
I muſt change names at home, and giue the Diſtaﬀe
Into my Husbands hands. This truſtie Seruant
Shall paſſe betweene vs: ere long you are like to heare
(If you dare venture in your owne behalfe)
A Miſtreſſes command. Weare this; ſpare ſpeech,
Decline your head. This kiſſe, if it durſt ſpeake
Would ſtretch thy Spirits vp into the ayre:
Conceiue, and fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Yours in the rankes of death.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: My moſt deere Gloſter.
Oh, the diﬀerence of man, and man,
To thee a Womans ſeruices are due,
My Foole vſurpes my body.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam, here come’s my Lord.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: I haue beene worth the whiſtle.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Oh Gonerill,
You are not worth the duſt which the rude winde
Blowes in your face.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Milke-Liuer’d man,
That bear’ſt a cheeke for blowes, a head for wrongs,
Who haſt not in thy browes an eye-diſcerning
Thine Honor, from thy ſuﬀering.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: See thy ſelfe diuell:
Proper deformitie ſeemes not in the Fiend
So horrid as in woman.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Oh vaine Foole.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Oh my good Lord, the Duke of Cornwals dead,
Slaine by his Seruant, going to put out
The other eye of Glouſter.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Glouſters eyes.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: A Seruant that he bred, thrill’d with remorſe,
Oppos’d againſt the aƈt: bending his Sword
To his great Maſter, who, threat-enrag’d
Flew on him, and among’ſt them fell’d him dead,
But not without that harmefull ſtroke, which ſince
Hath pluckt him after.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: This ſhewes you are aboue
You Iuſtices, that theſe our neather crimes
So ſpeedily can venge. But (O poore Glouſter)
Loſt he his other eye?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Both, both, my Lord.
This Leter Madam, craues a ſpeedy anſwer:
’Tis from your Siſter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: One way I like this well.
But being widdow, and my Glouſter with her,
May all the building in my fancie plucke
Vpon my hatefull life. Another way
The Newes is not ſo tart. Ile read, and anſwer.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Where was his Sonne,
When they did take his eyes?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Come with my Lady hither.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: He is not heere.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: No my good Lord, I met him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Knowes he the wickedneſſe?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I my good Lord: ’twas he inform’d againſt him
And quit the houſe on purpoſe, that their puniſhment
Might haue the freer courſe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Glouſter, I liue
To thanke thee for the loue thou ſhew’dſt the King,
And to reuenge thine eyes. Come hither Friend,
Tell me what more thou know’ſt.

scene.stagedir: Enter with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Gentlemen, and Souldiours.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Alacke, ’tis he: why he was met euen now
As mad as the vext Sea, ſinging alowd.
Crown’d with ranke Fenitar, and furrow weeds,
With Hardokes, Hemlocke, Nettles, Cuckoo ﬂowres,
Darnell, and all the idle weedes that grow
In our ſuſtaining Corne. A Centery ſend forth;
Search euery Acre in the high-growne ﬁeld,
And bring him to our eye. What can mans wiſedome
In the reſtoring his bereaued Senſe; he that helpes him,
Take all my outward worth.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: There is meanes Madam:
Our foſter Nurſe of Nature, is repoſe,
The which he lackes: that to prouoke in him
Are many Simples operatiue, whoſe power
Will cloſe the eye of Anguiſh.

speech.speaker: Cord.
speech.line: All bleſt Secrets,
All you vnpubliſh’d Vertues of the earth
Spring with my teares; be aydant, and remediate
In the Goodmans deſires: ſeeke, ſeeke for him,
Leaſt his vngouern’d rage, diſſolue the life
That wants the meanes to leade it.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Newes Madam,
The Brittiſh Powres are marching hitherward.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: ’Tis knowne before. Our preparation ſtands
In expeƈtation of them. O deere Father,
It is thy buſineſſe that I go about: Therfore great France
My mourning, and importun’d teares hath pittied:
No blowne Ambition doth our Armes incite,
But loue, deere loue, and our ag’d Fathers Rite:
Soone may I heare, and ſee him.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: But are my Brothers Powres ſet forth?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Himſelfe in perſon there?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam with much ado:
Your Siſter is the better Souldier.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Lord Edmund ſpake not with your Lord at home?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: No Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: What might import my Siſters Letter to him?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I know not, Lady.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Faith he is poaſted hence on ſerious matter:
It was great ignorance, Glouſters eyes being out
To let him liue. Where he arriues, he moues
All hearts againſt vs: Edmund, I thinke is gone
In pitty of his miſery, to diſpatch
His nighted life: Moreouer to deſcry
The ſtrength o’th’ Enemy.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I muſt needs after him, Madam, with my Letter.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Our troopes ſet forth to morrow, ſtay with vs:
The wayes are dangerous.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I may not Madam:
My Lady charg’d my dutie in this buſines.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Why ſhould ſhe write to Edmund?
Might not you tranſport her purpoſes by word? Belike,
Some things, I know not what. Ile loue thee much
Let me vnſeale the Letter.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Madam, I had rather —

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I know your Lady do’s not loue her Husband,
I am ſure of that: and at her late being heere,
She gaue ſtrange Eliads, and moſt ſpeaking lookes
To Noble Edmund. I know you are of her boſome.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I, Madam?

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I ſpeake in vnderſtanding: Y’are: I know’t,
Therefore I do aduiſe you take this note:
My Lord is dead: Edmond, and I haue talk’d,
And more conuenient is he for my hand
Then for your Ladies: You may gather more:
If you do ﬁnde him, pray you giue him this;
And when your Miſtris heares thus much from you,
I pray deſire her call her wiſedome to her.
So fare you well:
If you do chance to heare of that blinde Traitor,
Preferment fals on him, that cuts him oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Would I could meet Madam, I ſhould ſhew
What party I do follow.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: When ſhall I come to th’ top of that ſame hill?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: You do climbe vp it now. Look how we labor.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Me thinkes the ground is eeuen.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Horrible ſteepe.
Hearke, do you heare the Sea?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: No truly.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why then your other Senſes grow imperfeƈt
By your eyes anguiſh.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: So may it be indeed.
Me thinkes thy voyce is alter’d, and thou ſpeak’ſt
In better phraſe, and matter then thou did’ſt.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Y’are much deceiu’d: In nothing am I chang’d
But in my Garments.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Me thinkes y’are better ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Come on Sir,
Heere’s the place: ſtand ſtill: how fearefull
And dizie ’tis, to caſt ones eyes ſo low,
The Crowes and Choughes, that wing the midway ayre
Shew ſcarſe ſo groſſe as Beetles. Halfe way downe
Hangs one that gathers Sampire: dreadfull Trade:
Me thinkes he ſeemes no bigger then his head.
The Fiſhermen, that walk’d vpon the beach
Appeare like Mice: and yond tall Anchoring Barke,
Diminiſh’d to her Cocke: her Cocke, a Buoy
Almoſt too ſmall for ſight. The murmuring Surge,
That on th’ vnnumbred idle Pebble chafes
Cannot be heard ſo high. Ile looke no more,
Leaſt my braine turne, and the deﬁcient ſight
Topple downe headlong.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Set me where you ſtand.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your hand:
You are now within a foote of th’ extreme Verge:
For all beneath the Moone would I not leape vpright.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Let go my hand:
Heere Friend’s another purſe: in it, a Iewell
Well worth a poore mans taking. Fayries, and Gods
Proſper it with thee. Go thou further oﬀ,
Bid me farewell, and let me heare thee going.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Now fare ye well, good Sir.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: With all my heart.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Why I do triﬂe thus with his diſpaire,
Is done to cure it.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: O you mighty Gods!
This world I do renounce, and in your ſights
Shake patiently my great aﬀliƈtion oﬀ:
If I could beare it longer, and not fall
To quarrell with your great oppoſeleſſe willes,
My ſnuﬀe, and loathed part of Nature ſhould
Burne it ſelfe out. If Edgar liue, O bleſſe him:
Now Fellow, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Gone Sir, farewell:
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The Treaſury of life, when life it ſelfe
Yeelds to the Theft. Had he bin where he thought,
By this had thought bin paſt. Aliue, or dead?
Hoa, you Sir: Friend, heare you Sir, ſpeake:
Thus might he paſſe indeed: yet he reuiues.
What are you Sir?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Away, and let me dye.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Had’ſt thou beene ought
But Gozemore, Feathers, Ayre,
(So many fathome downe precipitating)
Thou’dſt ſhiuer’d like an Egge: but thou do’ſt breath:
Haſt heauy ſubſtance, bleed’ſt not, ſpeak’ſt, art ſound,
Ten Maſts at each, make not the altitude
Which thou haſt perpendicularly fell,
Thy life’s a Myracle. Speake yet againe.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: But haue I falne, or no?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: From the dread Somnet of this Chalkie Bourne
Looke vp a height, the ſhrill-gorg’d Larke ſo farre
Cannot be ſeene, or heard: Do but looke vp.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Alacke, I haue no eyes:
Is wretchedneſſe depriu’d that beneﬁt
To end it ſelfe by death? ’Twas yet ſome comfort,
When miſery could beguile the Tyrants rage,
And fruſtrate his proud will.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your arme.
Vp, ſo: How is’t? Feele you your Legges? You ſtand.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Too well, too well.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: This is aboue all ſtrangeneſſe,
Vpon the crowne o’th’ Cliﬀe. What thing was that
Which parted from you?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: A poore vnfortunate Beggar.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: As I ſtood heere below, me thought his eyes
Were two full Moones: he had a thouſand Noſes,
Hornes wealk’d, and waued like the enraged Sea:
It was ſome Fiend: Therefore thou happy Father,
Thinke that the cleereſt Gods, who make them Honors
Of mens Impoſſibilities, haue preſerued thee.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I do remember now: henceforth Ile beare
Aﬀliƈtion, till it do cry out it ſelfe
Enough, enough, and dye. That thing you ſpeake of,
I tooke it for a man: often ’twould ſay
The Fiend, the Fiend, he led me to that place.

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: Beare free and patient thoughts.
But who comes heere?
The ſafer ſenſe will ne’re accommodate
His Maſter thus.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, they cannot touch me for crying. I am the
King himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O thou ſide-piercing ſight!

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Nature’s aboue Art, in that reſpeƈt. Ther’s your
Preſſe-money. That fellow handles his bow, like a Crow-
keeper: draw mee a Cloathiers yard. Looke, looke, a
Mouſe: peace, peace, this peece of toaſted Cheeſe will
doo’t. There’s my Gauntlet, Ile proue it on a Gyant.
Bring vp the browne Billes. O well ﬂowne Bird: i’th’
clout, i’th’ clout: Hewgh. Giue the word.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Sweet Mariorum.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Paſſe.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I know that voice.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ha! Gonerill with a white beard? They ﬂatter’d
me like a Dogge, and told mee I had the white hayres in
my Beard, ere the blacke ones were there. To ſay I, and
no, to euery thing that I ſaid: I, and no too, was no good
Diuinity. When the raine came to wet me once, and the
winde to make me chatter: when the Thunder would not
peace at my bidding, there I found ’em, there I ſmelt ’em
out. Go too, they are not men o’their words; they told
me, I was euery thing: ’Tis a Lye, I am not Agu-proofe.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: The tricke of that voyce, I do well remember:
Is’t not the King?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I, euery inch a King.
When I do ſtare, ſee how the Subieƈt quakes.
I pardon that mans life. What was thy cauſe?
Adultery? thou ſhalt not dye: dye for Adultery?
No, the Wren goes too’t, and the ſmall gilded Fly
Do’s letcher in my ſight. Let Copulation thriue:
For Glouſters baſtard Son was kinder to his Father,
Then my Daughters got ’tweene the lawfull ſheets.
Too’t Luxury pell-mell, for I lacke Souldiers.
Behold yond ſimpring Dame, whoſe face betweene her
Forkes preſages Snow; that minces Vertue, & do’s ſhake
the head to heare of pleaſures name. The Fitchew, nor
the ſoyled Horſe goes too’t with a more riotous appe-
tite: Downe from the waſte they are Centaures, though
Women all aboue: but to the Girdle do the Gods inhe-
rit, beneath is all the Fiends. There’s hell, there’s darke-
nes, there is the ſulphurous pit; burning, ſcalding, ſtench,
conſumption: Fye, ﬁe, ﬁe; pah, pah: Giue me an Ounce
of Ciuet; good Apothecary ſweeten my immagination:
There’s money for thee.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: O let me kiſſe that hand.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Let me wipe it ﬁrſt,
It ſmelles of Mortality.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: O ruin’d peece of Nature, this great world
Shall ſo weare out to naught.
Do’ſt thou know me?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I remember thine eyes well enough: doſt thou
ſquiny at me? No, doe thy worſt blinde Cupid, Ile not
loue. Reade thou this challenge, marke but the penning
of it.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Were all thy Letters Sunnes, I could not ſee.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I would not take this from report,
It is, and my heart breakes at it.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Read.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: What with the Caſe of eyes?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Oh ho, are you there with me? No eies in your
head, nor no mony in your purſe? Your eyes are in a hea-
uy caſe, your purſe in a light, yet you ſee how this world
goes.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I ſee it feelingly.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What, art mad? A man may ſee how this world
goes, with no eyes. Looke with thine eares: See how
yond Iuſtice railes vpon yond ſimple theefe. Hearke in
thine eare: Change places, and handy-dandy, which is
the Iuſtice, which is the theefe: Thou haſt ſeene a Far-
mers dogge barke at a Beggar?

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: I Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And the Creature run from the Cur: there thou
might’ſt behold the great image of Authoritie, a Dogg’s
obey’d in Oﬃce. Thou, Raſcall Beadle, hold thy bloody
hand: why doſt thou laſh that Whore? Strip thy owne
backe, thou hotly luſts to vſe her in that kind, for which
thou whip’ſt her. The Vſurer hangs the Cozener. Tho-
rough tatter’d cloathes great Vices do appeare: Robes,
and Furr’d gownes hide all. Place ſinnes with Gold, and
the ſtrong Lance of Iuſtice, hurtleſſe breakes: Arme it in
ragges, a Pigmies ſtraw do’s pierce it. None do’s oﬀend,
none, I ſay none, Ile able ’em; take that of me my Friend,
who haue the power to ſeale th’ accuſers lips. Get thee
glaſſe-eyes, and like a ſcuruy Politician, ſeeme to ſee the
things thou doſt not. Now, now, now, now. Pull oﬀ my
Bootes: harder, harder, ſo.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: O matter, and impertinency mixt,
Reaſon in Madneſſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: If thou wilt weepe my Fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough, thy name is Glouſter:
Thou muſt be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know’ſt, the ﬁrſt time that we ſmell the Ayre
We wawle, and cry. I will preach to thee: Marke.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Alacke, alacke the day.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: When we are borne, we cry that we are come
To this great ſtage of Fooles. This a good blocke:
It were a delicate ſtratagem to ſhoo
A Troope of Horſe with Felt: Ile put’t in proofe,
And when I haue ſtolne vpon theſe Son in Lawes,
Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Oh heere he is: lay hand vpon him, Sir.
Your moſt deere Daughter —

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No reſcue? What, a Priſoner? I am euen
The Naturall Foole of Fortune. Vſe me well,
You ſhall haue ranſome. Let me haue Surgeons,
I am cut to’th’ Braines.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: You ſhall haue any thing.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No Seconds? All my ſelfe?
Why, this would make a man, a man of Salt
To vſe his eyes for Garden water-pots. I wil die brauely,
Like a ſmugge Bridegroome. What? I will be Iouiall:
Come, come, I am a King, Maſters, know you that?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: You are a Royall one, and we obey you.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Then there’s life in’t. Come, and you get it,
You ſhall get it by running: Sa, ſa, ſa, ſa.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: A ſight moſt pittifull in the meaneſt wretch,
Paſt ſpeaking of in a King. Thou haſt a Daughter
Who redeemes Nature from the generall curſe
Which twaine haue brought her to.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Haile gentle Sir.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Sir, ſpeed you: what’s your will?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Do you heare ought (Sir) of a Battell toward.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Moſt ſure, and vulgar:
Euery one heares that, which can diſtinguiſh ſound.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: But by your fauour:
How neere’s the other Army?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Neere, and on ſpeedy foot: the maine deſcry
Stands on the hourely thought.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I thanke you Sir, that’s all.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Though that the Queen on ſpecial cauſe is here
Her Army is mou’d on.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I thanke you Sir.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: You euer gentle Gods, take my breath from me,
Let not my worſer Spirit tempt me againe
To dye before you pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Well pray you Father.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Now good ſir, what are you?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: A moſt poore man, made tame to Fortunes blows
Who, by the Art of knowne, and feeling ſorrowes,
Am pregnant to good pitty. Giue me your hand,
Ile leade you to ſome biding.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Heartie thankes:
The bountie, and the benizon of Heauen
To boot, and boot.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: A proclaim’d prize: moſt happie
That eyeleſſe head of thine, was ﬁrſt fram’d ﬂeſh
To raiſe my fortunes. Thou old, vnhappy Traitor,
Breefely thy ſelfe remember: the Sword is out
That muſt deſtroy thee.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: Now let thy friendly hand
Put ſtrength enough too’t.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Wherefore, bold Pezant,
Dar’ſt thou ſupport a publiſh’d Traitor? Hence,
Leaſt that th’ infeƈtion of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arme.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Chill not let go Zir,
Without vurther ’caſion.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Let go Slaue, or thou dy’ſt.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Good Gentleman goe your gate, and let poore
volke paſſe: and ’chud ha’ bin zwaggerd out of my life,
’twould not ha’ bin zo long as ’tis, by a vortnight. Nay,
come not neere th’ old man: keepe out che vor’ ye, or ice
try whither your Coſtard, or my Ballow be the harder;
chill be plaine with you.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Out Dunghill.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Chill picke your teeth Zir: come, no matter vor
your foynes.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Slaue thou haſt ſlaine me: Villain, take my purſe;
If euer thou wilt thriue, bury my bodie,
And giue the Letters which thou ﬁnd’ſt about me,
To Edmund Earle of Glouſter: ſeeke him out
Vpon the Engliſh party. Oh vntimely death, death.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I know thee well. A ſeruiceable Villaine,
As duteous to the vices of thy Miſtris,
As badneſſe would deſire.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: What, is he dead?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Sit you downe Father: reſt you.
Let’s ſee theſe Pockets; the Letters that he ſpeakes of
May be my Friends: hee’s dead; I am onely ſorry
He had no other Deathſman. Let vs ſee:
Leaue gentle waxe, and manners: blame vs not
To know our enemies mindes, we rip their hearts,
Their Papers is more lawfull.

line.recite: Let our reciprocall vowes be remembred. You haue manie
opportunities to cut him oﬀ: if your will want not, time and
place will be fruitfully oﬀer’d. There is nothing done. If hee
returne the Conqueror, then am I the Priſoner, and his bed, my
Gaole, from the loathed warmth whereof, deliuer me, and ſup-
ply the place for your Labour.
Your (Wife, ſo I would ſay) aﬀeƈtio-
nate Seruant. Gonerill.

speech.line: Oh indiſtinguiſh’d ſpace of Womans will,
A plot vpon her vertuous Husbands life,
And the exchange my Brother: heere, in the ſands
Thee Ile rake vp, the poſte vnſanƈtiﬁed
Of murtherous Letchers: and in the mature time,
With this vngracious paper ſtrike the ſight
Of the death-praƈtis’d Duke: for him ’tis well,
That of thy death, and buſineſſe, I can tell.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: The King is mad:
How ſtiﬀe is my vilde ſenſe
That I ſtand vp, and haue ingenious feeling
Of my huge Sorrowes? Better I were diſtraƈt,
So ſhould my thoughts be ſeuer’d from my greefes,
And woes, by wrong imaginations looſe
The knowledge of themſelues.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Giue me your hand:
Farre oﬀ methinkes I heare the beaten Drumme.
Come Father, Ile beſtow you with a Friend.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O thou good Kent,
How ſhall I liue and worke
To match thy goodneſſe?
My life will be too ſhort,
And euery meaſure faile me.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: To be acknowledg’d Madam is ore-pai’d,
All my reports go with the modeſt truth,
Nor more, nor clipt, but ſo.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Be better ſuited,
Theſe weedes are memories of thoſe worſer houres:
I prythee put them oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Pardon deere Madam,
Yet to be knowne ſhortens my made intent,
My boone I make it, that you know me not,
Till time, and I, thinke meet.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Then be’t ſo my good Lord:
How do’s the King?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Madam ſleepes ſtill.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O you kind Gods!
Cure this great breach in his abuſed Nature,
Th’ vntun’d and iarring ſenſes, O winde vp,
Of this childe-changed Father.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Maieſty,
That we may wake the King, he hath ſlept long?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Be gouern’d by your knowledge, and proceede
I’th’ ſway of your owne will: is he array’d?

scene.stagedir: Enter Lear in a chaire carried by Seruants

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I Madam: in the heauineſſe of ſleepe,
We put freſh garments on him.
Be by good Madam when we do awake him,
I doubt of his Temperance.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O my deere Father, reſtauratian hang
Thy medicine on my lippes, and let this kiſſe
Repaire thoſe violent harmes, that my two Siſters
Haue in thy Reuerence made.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Kind and deere Princeſſe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Had you not bin their Father, theſe white ﬂakes
Did challenge pitty of them. Was this a face
To be oppos’d againſt the iarring windes?
Mine Enemies dogge, though he had bit me,
Should haue ſtood that night againſt my ﬁre,
And was’t thou faine (poore Father)
To houell thee with Swine and Rogues forlorne,
In ſhort, and muſty ſtraw? Alacke, alacke,
’Tis wonder that thy life and wits, at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes, ſpeake to him.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Madam do you, ’tis ﬁtteſt.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: How does my Royall Lord?
How fares your Maieſty?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You do me wrong to take me out o’th’ graue,
Thou art a Soule in bliſſe, but I am bound
Vpon a wheele of ﬁre, that mine owne teares
Do ſcal’d, like molten Lead.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Sir, do you know me?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You are a ſpirit I know, where did you dye?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Still, ſtill, farre wide.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: He’s ſcarſe awake,
Let him alone a while.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Where haue I bin?
Where am I? Faire day light?
I am mightily abus’d; I ſhould eu’n dye with pitty
To ſee another thus. I know not what to ſay:
I will not ſweare theſe are my hands: let’s ſee,
I feele this pin pricke, would I were aſſur’d
Of my condition.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: O looke vpon me Sir,
And hold your hand in benediƈtion o’re me,
You muſt not kneele.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Pray do not mocke me:
I am a very fooliſh fond old man,
Foureſcore and vpward,
Not an houre more, nor leſſe:
And to deale plainely,
I feare I am not in my perfeƈt mind.
Me thinkes I ſhould know you, and know this man,
Yet I am doubtfull: For I am mainely ignorant
What place this is: and all the skill I haue
Remembers not theſe garments: nor I know not
Where I did lodge laſt night. Do not laugh at me,
For (as I am a man) I thinke this Lady
To be my childe Cordelia.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: And ſo I am: I am.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Be your teares wet?
Yes faith: I pray weepe not,
If you haue poyſon for me, I will drinke it:
I know you do not loue me, for your Siſters
Haue (as I do remember) done me wrong.
You haue ſome cauſe, they haue not.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: No cauſe, no cauſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Am I in France?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: In your owne kingdome Sir.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Do not abuſe me.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Be comforted good Madam, the great rage
You ſee is kill’d in him: deſire him to go in,
Trouble him no more till further ſetling.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your Highneſſe walke?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You muſt beare with me:
Pray you now forget, and forgiue,
I am old and fooliſh.

scene.stagedir: Enter with Drumme and Colours, Edmund, Regan, Gentlemen, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Know of the Duke if his laſt purpoſe hold,
Or whether ſince he is aduis’d by ought
To change the courſe, he’s full of alteration,
And ſelfereprouing, bring his conſtant pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Our Siſters man is certainely miſcarried.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: ’Tis to be doubted Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Now ſweet Lord,
You know the goodneſſe I intend vpon you:
Tell me but truly, but then ſpeake the truth,
Do you not loue my Siſter?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: In honour’d Loue.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: But haue you neuer found my Brothers way,
To the fore-fended place?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: No by mine honour, Madam.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: I neuer ſhall endure her, deere my Lord
Be not familiar with her.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Feare not, ſhe and the Duke her husband.

scene.stagedir: Enter with Drum and Colours, Albany, Gonerill, Soldiers.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Our very louing Siſter, well be-met:
Sir, this I heard, the King is come to his Daughter
With others, whom the rigour of our State
Forc’d to cry out.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: Why is this reaſond?

speech.speaker: Gone.
speech.line: Combine together ’gainſt the Enemie:
For theſe domeſticke and particular broiles,
Are not the queſtion heere.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Let’s then determine with th’ ancient of warre
On our proceeding.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Siſter you’le go with vs?

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: ’Tis moſt conuenient, pray go with vs.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Oh ho, I know the Riddle, I will goe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: If ere your Grace had ſpeech with man ſo poore,
Heare me one word.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Ile ouertake you, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Before you ﬁght the Battaile, ope this Letter:
If you haue viƈtory, let the Trumpet ſound
For him that brought it: wretched though I ſeeme,
I can produce a Champion, that will proue
What is auouched there. If you miſcarry,
Your buſineſſe of the world hath ſo an end,
And machination ceaſes. Fortune loues you.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stay till I haue read the Letter.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: I was forbid it:
When time ſhall ſerue, let but the Herald cry,
And Ile appeare againe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Why farethee well, I will o’re-looke thy paper.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: The Enemy’s in view, draw vp your powers,
Heere is the gueſſe of their true ſtrength and Forces,
By dilligent diſcouerie, but your haſt
Is now vrg’d on you.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: We will greet the time.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: To both theſe Siſters haue I ſworne my loue:
Each iealous of the other, as the ſtung
Are of the Adder. Which of them ſhall I take?
Both? One? Or neither? Neither can be enioy’d
If both remaine aliue: To take the Widdow,
Exaſperates, makes mad her Siſter Gonerill,
And hardly ſhall I carry out my ſide,
Her husband being aliue. Now then, wee’l vſe
His countenance for the Battaile, which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him, deuiſe
His ſpeedy taking oﬀ. As for the mercie
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The Battaile done, and they within our power,
Shall neuer ſee his pardon: for my ſtate,
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.

scene.stagedir: Alarum within. Enter with Drumme and Colours, Lear, Cordelia, and Souldiers, ouer the Stage, and Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Heere Father, take the ſhadow of this Tree
For your good hoaſt: pray that the right may thriue:
If euer I returne to you againe,
Ile bring you comfort.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Grace go with you Sir.

speech.speaker: Edgar.
speech.line: Away old man, giue me thy hand, away:
King Lear hath loſt, he and his Daughter tane,
Giue me thy hand: Come on.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: No further Sir, a man may rot euen heere.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What in ill thoughts againe?
Men muſt endure
Their going hence, euen as their comming hither,
Ripeneſſe is all come on.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: And that’s true too.

scene.stagedir: Enter in conqueſt with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Lear, and Cordelia, as priſoners, Souldiers, Captaine.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Some Oﬃcers take them away: good guard,
Vntill their greater pleaſures ﬁrſt be knowne
That are to cenſure them.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: We are not the ﬁrſt,
Who with beſt meaning haue incurr’d the worſt:
For thee oppreſſed King I am caſt downe,
My ſelfe could elſe out-frowne falſe Fortunes frowne.
Shall we not ſee theſe Daughters, and theſe Siſters?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, no, no, no: come let’s away to priſon,
We two alone will ſing like Birds i’th’ Cage:
When thou doſt aske me bleſſing, Ile kneele downe
And aske of thee forgiueneſſe: So wee’l liue,
And pray, and ſing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded Butterﬂies: and heere (poore Rogues)
Talke of Court newes, and wee’l talke with them too,
Who looſes and who wins; who’s in, who’s out;
And take vpon’s the myſtery of things,
As if we were Gods ſpies: And wee’l weare out
In a wall’d priſon, packs and ſeƈts of great ones,
That ebbe and ﬂow by th’ Moone.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Take them away.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Vpon ſuch ſacriﬁces my Cordelia,
The Gods themſelues throw Incenſe.
Haue I caught thee?
He that parts vs, ſhall bring a Brand from Heauen,
And ﬁre vs hence, like Foxes: wipe thine eyes,
The good yeares ſhall deuoure them, ﬂeſh and fell,
Ere they ſhall make vs weepe?
Weele ſee ’em ſtaru’d ﬁrſt: come.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Come hither Captaine, hearke.
Take thou this note, go follow them to priſon,
One ſtep I haue aduanc’d thee, if thou do’ſt
As this inſtruƈts thee, thou doſt make thy way
To Noble Fortunes: know thou this, that men
Are as the time is; to be tender minded
Do’s not become a Sword, thy great imployment
Will not beare queſtion: either ſay thou’lt do’t,
Or thriue by other meanes.

speech.speaker: Capt.
speech.line: Ile do’t my Lord.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: About it, and write happy, when th’ haſt done,
Marke I ſay inſtantly, and carry it ſo
As I haue ſet it downe. Exit Captaine.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Albany, Gonerill, Regan, Soldiers.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Sir, you haue ſhew’d to day your valiant ſtraine
And Fortune led you well: you haue the Captiues
Who were the oppoſites of this dayes ſtrife:
I do require them of you ſo to vſe them,
As we ſhall ﬁnd their merites, and our ſafety
May equally determine.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Sir, I thought it ﬁt,
To ſend the old and miſerable King to ſome retention,
Whoſe age had Charmes in it, whoſe Title more,
To plucke the common boſome on his ſide,
And turne our impreſt Launces in our eies
Which do command them. With him I ſent the Queen:
My reaſon all the ſame, and they are ready
To morrow, or at further ſpace, t’ appeare
Where you ſhall hold your Seſſion.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Sir, by your patience,
I hold you but a ſubieƈt of this Warre,
Not as a Brother.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: That’s as we liſt to grace him.
Methinkes our pleaſure might haue bin demanded
Ere you had ſpoke ſo farre. He led our Powers,
Bore the Commiſſion of my place and perſon,
The which immediacie may well ſtand vp,
And call it ſelfe your Brother.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Not ſo hot:
In his owne grace he doth exalt himſelfe,
More then in your addition.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: In my rights,
By me inueſted, he compeeres the beſt.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: That were the moſt, if he ſhould husband you.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Ieſters do oft proue Prophets.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Hola, hola,
That eye that told you ſo, look’d but a ſquint.

speech.speaker: Rega.
speech.line: Lady I am not well, elſe I ſhould anſwere
From a full ﬂowing ſtomack. Generall,
Take thou my ſouldiers, priſoners, patrimony,
Diſpoſe of them, of me, the walls is thine:
Witneſſe the world, that I create thee heere
My Lord, and Maſter.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Meane you to enioy him?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: The let alone lies not in your good will.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Nor in thine Lord.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Halfe-blooded fellow, yes.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Let the Drum ſtrike, and proue my title thine.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Stay yet, heare reaſon: Edmund, I arreſt thee
On capitall Treaſon; and in thy arreſt,
This guilded Serpent: for your claime faire Siſters,
I bare it in the intereſt of my wife,
’Tis ſhe is ſub-contraƈted to this Lord,
And I her husband contradiƈt your Banes.
If you will marry, make your loues to me,
My Lady is beſpoke.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: An enterlude.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Thou art armed Gloſter,
Let the Trumpet ſound:
If none appeare to proue vpon thy perſon,
Thy heynous, manifeſt, and many Treaſons,
There is my pledge: Ile make it on thy heart
Ere I taſte bread, thou art in nothing leſſe
Then I haue heere proclaim’d thee.

speech.speaker: Reg.
speech.line: Sicke, O ſicke.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: If not, Ile nere truſt medicine.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: There’s my exchange, what in the world hes
That names me Traitor, villain-like he lies,
Call by the Trumpet: he that dares approach;
On him, on you, who not, I will maintaine
My truth and honor ﬁrmely.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: A Herald, ho.
Truſt to thy ſingle vertue, for thy Souldiers
All leuied in my name, haue in my name
Tooke their diſcharge.

speech.speaker: Regan.
speech.line: My ſickneſſe growes vpon me.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: She is not well, conuey her to my Tent.
Come hither Herald, let the Trumpet ſound,
And read out this. A Trumpet ſounds.

line.recite: If any man of qualitie or degree, within the liſts of the Ar-
my, will maintaine vpon Edmund, ſuppoſed Earle of Gloſter,
that he is a manifold Traitor, let him appeare by the third
ſound of the Trumpet: he is bold in his defence.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: Againe. 2 Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: Againe. 3 Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Aske him his purpoſes, why he appeares
Vpon this Call o’th’ Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: What are you?
Your name, your quality, and why you anſwer
This preſent Summons?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Know my name is loſt
By Treaſons tooth: bare-gnawne, and Canker-bit,
Yet am I Noble as the Aduerſary
I come to cope.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Which is that Aduerſary?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What’s he that ſpeakes for Edmund Earle of Gloſter?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Himſelfe, what ſaiſt thou to him?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Draw thy Sword,
That if my ſpeech oﬀend a Noble heart,
Thy arme may do thee Iuſtice, heere is mine:
Behold it is my priuiledge,
The priuiledge of mine Honours,
My oath, and my profeſſion. I proteſt,
Maugre thy ſtrength, place, youth, and eminence,
Deſpiſe thy viƈtor-Sword, and ﬁre new Fortune,
Thy valor, and thy heart, thou art a Traitor:
Falſe to thy Gods, thy Brother, and thy Father,
Conſpirant ’gainſt this high illuſtrious Prince,
And from th’ extremeſt vpward of thy head,
To the diſcent and duſt below thy foote,
A moſt Toad-spotted Traitor. Say thou no,
This Sword, this arme, and my beſt ſpirits are bent
To proue vpon thy heart, where to I ſpeake,
Thou lyeſt.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: In wiſedome I ſhould aske thy name,
But ſince thy out-side lookes ſo faire and Warlike,
And that thy tongue (ſome ſay) of breeding breathes,
What ſafe, and nicely I might well delay,
By rule of Knight-hood, I diſdaine and ſpurne:
Backe do I toſſe theſe Treaſons to thy head,
With the hell-hated Lye, ore-whelme thy heart,
Which for they yet glance by, and ſcarcely bruiſe,
This Sword of mine ſhall giue them inſtant way,
Where they ſhall reſt for euer. Trumpets ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Saue him, ſaue him.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: This is praƈtiſe Gloſter,
By th’ law of Warre, thou waſt not bound to anſwer
An vnknowne oppoſite: thou art not vanquiſh’d,
But cozend, and beguild.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Shut your mouth Dame,
Or with this paper ſhall I ſtop it: hold Sir,
Thou worſe then any name, reade thine owne euill:
No tearing Lady, I perceiue you know it.

speech.speaker: Gon.
speech.line: Say if I do, the Lawes are mine not thine,
Who can araigne me for’t?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Moſt monſtrous! O, know’ſt thou this paper?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Aske me not what I know.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Go after her, ſhe’s deſperate, gouerne her.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: What you haue charg’d me with,
That haue I done,
And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
’Tis paſt, and ſo am I: But what art thou
That haſt this Fortune on me? If thou’rt Noble,
I do forgiue thee.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Let’s exchange charity:
I am no leſſe in blood then thou art Edmond,
If more, the more th’ haſt wrong’d me.
My name is Edgar and thy Fathers Sonne,
The Gods are iuſt, and of our pleaſant vices
Make inſtruments to plague vs:
The darke and vitious place where thee he got,
Coſt him his eyes.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Th’haſt ſpoken right, ’tis true,
The Wheele is come full circle, I am heere.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Me thought thy very gate did propheſie
A Royall Nobleneſſe: I muſt embrace thee,
Let ſorrow ſplit my heart, if euer I
Did hate thee, or thy Father.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Worthy Prince I know’t.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Where haue you hid your ſelfe?
How haue you knowne the miſeries of your Father?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: By nurſing them my Lord. Liſt a breefe tale,
And when ’tis told, O that my heart would burſt.
The bloody proclamation to eſcape
That follow’d me ſo neere, (O our liues ſweetneſſe,
That we the paine of death would hourely dye,
Rather then die at once) taught me to ſhift
Into a mad-mans rags, t’ aſſume a ſemblance
That very Dogges diſdain’d: and in this habit
Met I my Father with his bleeding Rings,
Their precious Stones new loſt: became his guide,
Led him, begg’d for him, ſau’d him from diſpaire.
Neuer (O fault) reueal’d my ſelfe vnto him,
Vntill ſome halfe houre paſt when I was arm’d,
Not ſure, though hoping of this good ſucceſſe,
I ask’d his bleſſing, and from ﬁrſt to laſt
Told him our pilgrimage. But his ﬂaw’d heart
(Alacke too weake the conﬂiƈt to ſupport)
Twixt two extremes of paſſion, ioy and greefe,
Burſt ſmilingly.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: This ſpeech of yours hath mou’d me,
And ſhall perchance do good, but ſpeake you on,
You looke as you had ſomething more to ſay.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: If there be more, more wofull, hold it in,
For I am almoſt ready to diſſolue,
Hearing of this.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Helpe, helpe: O helpe.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What kinde of helpe?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Speake man.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: What meanes this bloody Knife?

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: ’Tis hot, it ſmoakes, it came euen from the heart
of — O ſhe’s dead.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Who dead? Speake man.

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: Your Lady Sir, your Lady; and her Siſter
By her is poyſon’d: ſhe confeſſes it.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I was contraƈted to them both, all three
Now marry in an inſtant.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Here comes Kent.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Produce the bodies, be they aliue or dead;

line.stagedir: Gonerill and Regans bodies brought out.

speech.line: This iudgement of the Heauens that makes vs tremble.
Touches vs not with pitty: O, is this he?
The time will not allow the complement
Which very manners vrges.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I am come
To bid my King and Maſter aye good night.
Is he not here?

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Great thing of vs forgot,
Speake Edmund, where’s the King? and where’s Cordelia?
Seeſt thou this obieƈt Kent?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Alacke, why thus?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Yet Edmund was belou’d:
The one the other poiſon’d for my ſake,
And after ſlew herſelfe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Euen ſo: couer their faces.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I pant for life: ſome good I meane to do
Deſpight of mine owne Nature. Quickly ſend,
(Be briefe in it) to’th’ Caſtle, for my Writ
Is on the life of Lear, and on Cordelia:
Nay, ſend in time.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Run, run, O run.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: To who my Lord? Who ha’s the Oﬃce?
Send thy token of repreeue.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Well thought on, take my Sword,
Giue it the Captaine.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Haſt thee for thy life.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: He hath Commiſſion from thy Wife and me,
To hang Cordelia in the priſon, and
To lay the blame vpon her owne diſpaire,
That ſhe for-did her ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: The Gods defend her, beare him hence awhile.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Howle, howle, howle: O you are men of ſtones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, Il’d vſe them ſo,
That Heauens vault ſhould crack: ſhe’s gone for euer.
I know when one is dead, and when one liues,
She’s dead as earth: Lend me a Looking-glaſſe,
If that her breath will miſt or ſtaine the ſtone,
Why then ſhe liues.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Is this the promis’d end?

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Or image of that horror.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Fall and ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This feather ſtirs, ſhe liues: if it be ſo,
It is a chance which do’s redeeme all ſorrowes
That euer I haue felt.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: O my good Maſter.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Prythee away.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: ’Tis Noble Kent your Friend.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A plague vpon you Murderors, Traitors all,
I might haue ſau’d her, now ſhe’s gone for euer:
Cordelia, Cordelia, ſtay a little. Ha:
What is’t thou ſaiſt? Her voice was euer ſoft,
Gentle, and low, an excellent thing in woman.
I kill’d the Slaue that was a hanging thee.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: ’Tis true (my Lords) he did.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Did I not fellow?
I haue ſeene the day, with my good biting Faulchion
I would haue made him skip: I am old now,
And theſe ſame croſſes ſpoile me. Who are you?
Mine eyes are not o’th’ beſt, Ile tell you ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: If Fortune brag of two, ſhe lou’d and hated,
One of them we behold.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: This is a dull ſight, are you not Kent?

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: The ſame: your Seruant Kent,
Where is your Seruant Caius?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that,
He’le ſtrike and quickly too, he’s dead and rotten.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: No my good Lord, I am the very man.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Ile ſee that ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: That from your ﬁrſt of diﬀerence and decay,
Haue follow’d your ſad ſteps.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You are welcome hither.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Nor no man elſe:
All’s cheerleſſe, darke, and deadly,
Your eldeſt Daughters haue fore-done themſelues,
And deſperately are dead

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I ſo I thinke.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: He knowes not what he ſaies, and vaine is it
That we preſent vs to him.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Very bootleſſe.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Edmund is dead my Lord.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: That’s but a triﬂe heere:
You Lords and Noble Friends, know our intent,
What comfort to this great decay may come,
Shall be appli’d. For vs we will reſigne,
During the life of this old Maieſty
To him our abſolute power, you to your rights,
With boote, and ſuch addition as your Honours
Haue more then merited. All Friends ſhall
Taſte the wages of their vertue, and all Foes
The cup of their deſeruings: O ſee, ſee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: And my poore Foole is hang’d: no, no, no life?
Why ſhould a Dog, a Horſe, a Rat haue life,
And thou no breath at all? Thou’lt come no more,
Neuer, neuer, neuer, neuer, neuer.
Pray you vndo this Button. Thanke you Sir,
Do you ſee this? Looke on her? Looke her lips,
Looke there, looke there. He dies.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: He faints, my Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Breake heart, I prythee breake.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: Looke vp my Lord.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: Vex not his ghoſt, O let him paſſe, he hates him,
That would vpon the wracke of this tough world
Stretch him out longer.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: He is gon indeed.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: The wonder is, he hath endur’d ſo long,
He but vſurpt his life.

speech.speaker: Alb.
speech.line: Beare them from hence, our preſent buſineſſe
Is generall woe: Friends of my ſoule, you twaine,
Rule in this Realme, and the gor’d ſtate ſuſtaine.

speech.speaker: Kent.
speech.line: I haue a iourney Sir, ſhortly to go,
My Maſter calls me, I muſt not ſay no.

speech.speaker: Edg.
speech.line: The waight of this ſad time we muſt obey,
Speake what we feele, not what we ought to ſay:
The oldeſt hath borne moſt, we that are yong,
Shall neuer ſee ſo much, nor liue ſo long.
